'''Bernard Fisher''' may refer to:
==People== * [[Bernard Fisher (footballer)]] (born c. 1930), English footballer * [[Bernard Fisher (scientist)]] (born 1918), researcher in cancer chemotherapy * [[Bernard Francis Fisher]], U.S. Air Force colonel and Medal of Honor recipient * [[Red Fisher (sportsman)]] (Bernard Herbert Fisher, 1914–2006), American sporting goods retailer, columnist and poet, later a radio and television personality in Canada
==Other== * [[MV Maj. Bernard F. Fisher (T-AK-4396)|MV ''Maj. Bernard F. Fisher'' (T-AK-4396)]], U.S. Navy vessel named for Bernard Francis Fisher

{{distinguish|Gunpowder Plot}} {{Infobox military conflict | image = PowderMagazineinWilliamsburg.jpg | image_size = 300 | caption = The powder magazine in Williamsburg from which the gunpowder was removed | conflict = Gunpowder Incident | partof = the [[American Revolutionary War]] | date = April 20, 1775 | place = [[Williamsburg, Virginia]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|16|14.66|N|76|41|59.98|W|type:event_region:US-VA_dim:20|display=title}} | result = British sailors remove military supplies
Militia uprising peacefully resolved | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox American Revolutionary War: Southern 1775-1779}} }} The '''Gunpowder Incident''' (or '''Gunpowder Affair''') was a conflict early in the [[American Revolutionary War]] between [[John Murray, 4th Earl of Dunmore|Lord Dunmore]], the Royal Governor of the [[Colony of Virginia]], and [[militia]] led by [[Patrick Henry]]. On April 20, 1775, one day after the [[Battles of Lexington and Concord]] (and well before news of that event reached Virginia), Lord Dunmore ordered the removal of the [[gunpowder]] from the [[gunpowder magazine|magazine]] in [[Williamsburg, Virginia]] to a [[Royal Navy]] ship. This action sparked local unrest, and militia companies began mustering throughout the colony. [[Patrick Henry]] led a small militia force toward Williamsburg to force return of the gunpowder to the colony's control. The matter was resolved without conflict when a payment of [[Pound sterling|£]]330 was made to Henry. Dunmore, fearing for his personal safety, later retreated to a naval vessel, ending royal control of the colony. ==Background== Military tensions began to rise in the [[Thirteen Colonies|British colonies of North America]] in 1774 when a series of legislative acts by the British Parliament known as the [[Intolerable Acts]] began to be implemented in the colonies. The colonies, in solidarity with the [[Province of Massachusetts Bay]], which had been singled out for punishment by those acts in the wake of the [[Boston Tea Party]], had organized a Congress to meet in September 1774.Russell, pp. 45–46 During the meeting of the [[First Continental Congress]] word arrived of a militia uprising in Massachusetts that became known as the [[Powder Alarm]]. In early September, General [[Thomas Gage]], the royal governor of Massachusetts, had removed gunpowder from a powder magazine in [[Charlestown, Massachusetts|Charlestown]] (in a location now in [[Somerville, Massachusetts|Somerville]]), and militia from all over [[New England]] had flocked to the area in response to false rumors that violence had been involved.Richmond, p. 6Russell, p. 48 One consequence of this action was that the Congress called for the colonies to organize militia companies for their defense. Another was that [[William Legge, 2nd Earl of Dartmouth|Lord Dartmouth]], the [[Secretary of State for the Colonies]], advised the colonial governors to secure their military supplies, and prohibited importation of further supplies of powder. In early 1775, Virginians began to organize militia companies and seek out military supplies (weapons, ammunition, and gunpowder) to arm and equip them. [[John Murray, 4th Earl of Dunmore|Lord Dunmore]], [[Colony of Virginia|Virginia]]'s royal governor, saw this rising unrest in his colony and sought to deprive Virginia militia of these supplies.Selby and Higginbotham, p. 1 It was not until after [[Patrick Henry]]'s "[[Give me liberty or give me death]]" speech at the [[Second Virginia Convention]] on March 23 that Dunmore "[thought] it prudent to remove some Gunpowder which was in a Magazine in this place."Williamson, p. 54 Although British Army troops had been withdrawn from Virginia in the wake of the Powder Alarm, there were several Royal Navy ships in the Virginia waters of [[Chesapeake Bay]]. On April 19, Lord Dunmore quietly brought a company of British sailors into [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]] and quartered them in the governor's mansion. Dunmore then ordered Captain [[Henry Collins (Royal Navy officer)|Henry Collins]], commander of [[HMS Magdalen|HMS ''Magdalen'']], to remove the gunpowder from the magazine in Williamsburg. ==Removing the gunpowder== [[File:Williamsburg magazine drawing exterior.gif|thumb|right|Drawing of the octagonal Williamsburg Magazine]] On the night of April 20, Royal Navy sailors went to the Williamsburg powder magazine, loaded fifteen half barrels of powder into the governor's wagon, and transported it to the eastern end of the [[Quarterpath Road]] to be loaded aboard the ''Magdalen'' in the [[James River (Virginia)|James River]]. The act was discovered by townsfolk while underway, and they sounded an alarm. Local militia rallied to the scene, and riders spread word of the incident across the colony. Dunmore had as a precaution armed his servants with muskets, and it was only the calming words of Patriot leaders, including the Speaker of the [[Virginia House of Burgesses|House of Burgesses]], [[Peyton Randolph]], that prevented the assembling crowd from storming Dunmore's mansion.Russell, p. 52 The city council demanded the return of the powder, claiming it was the property of the colony and not [[the Crown]]. Dunmore demurred, stating that he was moving the powder as protection against its seizure during a rumored slave uprising, and would eventually return it. This seemed to satisfy the assembled crowd, and it dispersed peacefully.Selby and Higginbotham, p. 2 Unrest however persisted in Williamsburg and spread throughout the countryside. After a second crowd was convinced to disperse by Patriot leaders, Dunmore reacted angrily, warning on April 22 that if attacked, he would "declare Freedom to the Slaves, and reduce the City of Williamsburg to Ashes." He also told a Williamsburg [[alderman]] that he had "once fought for the Virginians" but "By God, I would let them see that I could fight against them."Selby and Higginbotham, p. 3 [[File:Patrick henry.JPG|thumb|left|upright=0.5|[[Patrick Henry]], portrait by George Bagby Matthews c. 1891 after an original by [[Thomas Sully]]]] By April 29, militia mobilizing in the countryside had learned of the battles at Lexington and Concord. Nearly 700 men mustered at [[Fredericksburg, Virginia|Fredericksburg]], and decided to send a messenger to Williamsburg to assess the situation before marching on the capital. Peyton Randolph advised against violence, and [[George Washington]], a longtime leader of the Virginia militia, concurred. In response to their advice, the Fredericksburg militia voted by a narrow margin not to march.Russell, p. 53 However, militia from other parts of the colony did march to Williamsburg. The [[Hanover County, Virginia|Hanover County]] militia, led by Patrick Henry, voted on May 2 to march on Williamsburg. Henry dispatched a small company to the home of Richard Corbin, who was the Deputy Collector of the Royal Revenue in Virginia, in a bid to force him to pay for the powder from Crown revenue in his possession; the remainder of the Hanover County militia, numbering about 150, marched toward Williamsburg, arriving about {{convert|15|mi|km}} away on May 3. That day Dunmore's family escaped Williamsburg to [[Porto Bello (Williamsburg, Virginia)|Porto Bello]], Lord Dunmore's hunting lodge on the [[York River (Virginia)|York River]], and from there to {{HMS|Fowey|1749|6}}, lying at anchor in the York River.{{cite journal |title=Numerous Errors in Wilstach's 'Tidewater Virginia' Challenge Criticism |last= Kibler |first=J. Luther |journal=[[William and Mary Quarterly]] | series = 2nd Ser. |volume=11 |issue=2 |date=April 1931 |pages=152–156 |doi=10.2307/1921010 |publisher=Omohundro Institute of Early American History and Culture |jstor=1921010 }} Corbin was not at home—he was in Williamsburg, meeting with Dunmore.Selby and Higginbotham, p. 4 Henry was advised by [[Carter Braxton]], Corbin's son-in-law and a Patriot member of the House of Burgesses, not to enter the city, while Braxton rode into the city and negotiated a payment. The next day, May 4, Henry received a [[bill of exchange]] for £330 signed by a wealthy plantation owner, as payment for the powder (he refused the offer of payment from Crown accounts). Henry then departed to take his place as a member of Virginia's delegation to the [[Second Continental Congress]], promising to deliver the money to "the Virginia Delegates at the General congress".Vaughan, p. 88 On May 6 Dunmore issued a proclamation charging Henry with extortion of the £330, and forbidding the citizenry to assist Henry in any way. Henry was offered protection by several counties, and was escorted by several companies of militia to the Maryland border as he made his way to [[Philadelphia]].Selby and Higginbotham, p. 5 ==Aftermath== [[File:Sir Joshua Reynolds - John Murray, 4th Earl of Dunmore - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.5|Portrait of Dunmore by Sir [[Joshua Reynolds]], 1765]] The incident burnished Henry's reputation while worsening Dunmore's popularity.Vaughan, p. 89 Although his family briefly returned to Williamsburg on May 12 as a sign of good faith, relations between Dunmore and the House of Burgesses continued to deteriorate. On June 8, Dunmore and his family fled the [[Governor's Palace (Williamsburg, Virginia)|Governor's Palace]] in the middle of the night and took up residence aboard ''Fowey''.Selby and Higginbotham, pp. 41–43 The Burgesses had been deliberating the [[Conciliatory Resolution]], a proposal that was an attempt by the [[North Ministry]] to divide the colonies. In the wake of Dunmore's flight, the Burgesses rejected the proposal.Selby and Higginbotham, p. 44 Dunmore continued to make vigorous attempts to regain control of the colony, but after a decisive defeat of British forces [[Battle of Great Bridge|at Great Bridge]] in December, he was reduced to raiding operations and eventually abandoned the colony for good in August 1776.Russell, pp. 68–76 Virginia's government was first taken over by a [[Committee of Safety (American Revolution)|Committee of Safety]], chosen by the [[Third Virginia Convention]] in July 1775; Patrick Henry became the independent state's first [[Governor of Virginia|governor]] in July 1776.Selby and Higginbotham, pp. 52,121 ==See also== * [[Powder Alarm]], a similar episode in Massachusetts ==Notes== {{reflist|colwidth=24em}} ==References== *{{cite book|title=Powder Alarm 1774|first=Robert P|last=Richmond|publisher=Auerbach|year=1971|ref=Richmond|isbn=978-0-87769-073-3|location=Princeton, NJ|oclc=162197}} *{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5DFy0eWaPxIC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72| title=The American Revolution in the Southern colonies | first=David Lee|last= Russell| publisher=McFarland| year=2000| isbn=978-0-7864-0783-5 |location=Jefferson, NC| oclc=248087936}} *{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WfCBYZs_jIMC&pg=PA62|title=The Revolution in Virginia, 1775–1783|first=John E|last=Selby|author2=Higginbotham, Don|publisher=Colonial Williamsburg|year=2007|isbn=978-0-87935-233-2|ref=Selby|oclc=124076712|location=Williamsburg, VA}} *{{cite book|last=Vaughan|first=David|title=Give Me Liberty: the Uncompromising Statesmanship of Patrick Henry|publisher=Cumberland House Publishing|year=1997|location=Nashville, TN|isbn=978-1-888952-22-3|oclc=36372369}} ==External links== *[http://www.revwar75.com/battles/primarydocs/williamsburg.htm "Primary Documents Relating to the Seizure of Powder at Williamsburg, VA, April 21, 1775"] *[http://research.history.org/pf/viewer.cfm?image=newspapers/lg_gunpowderart1.jpg|newspapers/lg_gunpowderart2.jpg&imageTitle=Virginia%20Gazette&imageSubTitle=The%20Gunpowder%20Incident Old Virginia Gazette article on the Gunpowder Incident] *[http://earlyamerica.com/review/2004_summer_fall/proclamation.htm Proclamation against Patrick Henry] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051203055908/http://colonialwilliamsburg.com/Almanack/places/hb/hbmag.cfm Colonial Williamsburg – Magazine (including the Gunpowder Incident)] {{Virginia during the American Revolutionary War}} {{Good article}} [[Category:1775 in the Thirteen Colonies]] [[Category:American Revolution]] [[Category:American Revolutionary War]] [[Category:Virginia in the American revision.comment: Removing [[:c:File:Plan-international-usa-logo.svg|Plan-international-usa-logo.svg]], it has been deleted from Commons by [[:c:User:JuTa|JuTa]] because: No [[:c:COM:Source|source]] since 21 August 2019.
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Plan International USA | logo = | type = [[501(c)#501(c)(3)|501(c)(3)]] [[charitable organization]] | founded_date = {{start date and age|1937}} (as Foster Parents Plan for Children in Spain) | founders = [[John Langdon-Davies]]
Eric Muggeridge | location = [[Warwick, Rhode Island]], [[Washington D.C.]] | key_people = John Langdon-Davies, [[Laurie Metcalf]], Tessie San Martin | area_served = Bangladesh, Benin, Bolivia, Brazil, Burkina Faso, Cambodia, Cameroon, China, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, El Salvador, Ethiopia, Ghana, Guatemala, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Haiti, Honduras, India, Indonesia, Kenya, Laos, Liberia, Malawi, Mali, Mozambique, Nepal, Nicaragua, Niger, Pakistan, Philippines, Paraguay, Peru, Rwanda, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Tanzania, Thailand, [[Timor-Leste]], Togo, Uganda, Vietnam, Zambia, Zimbabwe | focus = Child sponsorship, child poverty, global development | method = | revenue = [[US$]] 63.5 Million (2010) | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 97 | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = {{URL|planusa.org}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Plan International USA''' is an international [[charitable organization|charity]] with offices in [[Warwick, Rhode Island]] and [[Washington, D.C.]], United States. It is part of [[Plan International]], a global non-profit organization. The stated goal of the organization is to end the [[cycle of poverty]] for children by working side by side with local communities.[https://www.planusa.org/what-we-do, Plan International USA, What We Do] ==History and development== {{Main|Plan International}} Plan was founded in 1937 by British journalist [[John Langdon-Davies]] and refugee worker Eric Muggeridge."[http://www.universalgiving.org/donate/plan_international_usa_former/id567.do Plan International USA (formerly Childreach)]" summary on Universal Giving page (accessed Oct. 9 2012) Originally named "Foster Parents Plan for Children in Spain," the aim was to provide food, accommodation and education to children whose lives had been disrupted by the [[Spanish Civil War]]. During the [[Second World War]], under the name "Foster Parents Plan for War Children,"[http://www.uri.edu/library/special_collections/registers/manuscripts/msg223.xml Foster Parent’s Plan for War Children Letters 1942-1997], University of Rhode Island Special collections page accessed Oct. 9, 2012 the organization expanded to work with displaced children throughout war-torn Europe. By the 1970s, Plan gradually began working with children throughout Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean. 1970s Plan International USA, was originally [[incorporation (business)|incorporated]] as "Foster Parents Plan, Inc.,"Plan International USA, [http://www.planusa.org/content2714575 Celebrating our 75th Anniversary] (accessed Oct. 9 2012) in 1939 in [[New York (state)|New York]][http://www.pbn.com/Involving-communities-key-to-Plan-USA-success-abroad,54449 "Involving communities key to Plan USA success abroad," ''Providence Business News''] to help connect U.S. donors to a continuously growing number of sponsored children in developing countries. It was one of the first Plan International federation members. By 2010, Plan's donor countries had increased to 21.[http://www.planusa.org/who_where/who_where.php Plan USA Where We Work] ===Name Change=== In 1974, the international parent organization Foster Parents Plan shortened its name to become simply Plan International.[http://plancanada.ca/ForSponsors/PlansStory Plan's Story] (accessed Oct. 9 2012) In the 1990s the U.S. organization followed suit, with a name change to "Childreach/Plan International" to avoid the program confused with local [[foster care]] programs,[http://www.lippincott.com/work/childreach/ Lippincott Brand Strategy and Design, "Childreach"] (accessed Oct. 9 2012) and then simply to "Plan International USA". == Finances == Plan International USA is a publicly funded American non-profit charitable organization, deriving its income from a combination of individual contributions and private and [[federal grants]].[http://www.pbn.com/detail.html?sub_id=545fbc8f5ec4&page=3 Overseas spending by nonprofit a boost to U.S. security | Providence Business News] It is exempt from both United States federal and Rhode Island state income tax.{{Cite web|url=http://give.org/charity-reviews/national/relief-and-development/plan-international-usa-in-warwick-ri-2809|title=Charity Report - Plan International USA - give.org|website=give.org}} The total operating revenue in 2010 for the organization was approximately $63 million. 77% of the organization's funding was reported to go to programs, while 23% was reported as support for programming through fundraising and administrative expenses.{{Cite web|url=http://give.org/charity-reviews/national/relief-and-development/plan-international-usa-in-warwick-ri-2809|title=Charity Report - Plan International USA - give.org|website=give.org}} == Programs == In coordination with Plan International and its other chapters, in 2010 Plan International USA helped fund and organize the following combined international programs and activities: * The construction or rehabilitation of 1,935 health or early childhood care and development centers, 1,251 schools and 7,531 water points; * Improvement of sanitation facilities for 90,882 households; * Support for 767 [[microfinance]] organizations and 13,636 local savings and loan groups; * Training for 150,007 professional and volunteer health workers; * Training for 58,229 professional and volunteer education workers; * Training for 70,917 workers and farmers; * Vocational and business training to 26,770 people; * Training for 43,124 members of staff or partner organization staff and 106,544 community members in child protection;[http://www.planusa.org/docs/planusaannual10.pdf Plan USA Annual Report 2010] * Increased disaster relief activities in Haiti;{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/11/idUS225441+11-Jan-2011+PRN20110111|title=Plan International USA's Stepped Up Relief Operations in Haiti Continue to Make Progress | Reuters}} * The beginning of a program to prevent and treat HIV and other related diseases in Benin, Togo and Cameroon, funded by the Global Fund.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pnnonline.org/|title=PNNOnline - Información, y notas sobre actualidad y sexo|website=PNNOnline}} ===U.S. programs=== YUGA, Youth United in Global Action, is a program sponsored by Plan International USA. YUGA aims to educate and involve young people in the United States in issues that affect children and youth around the world. The program's main focus areas are: [[climate change]], [[global poverty]], [[HIV]] and [[AIDS]], [[child rights]] and child exploitation, and [[gender equality]].[http://www.pbn.com/detail.html?sub_id=545fbc8f5ec4&page=2 Overseas spending by nonprofit a boost to U.S. security | Providence Business News] ===Child sponsorship=== The [[child sponsorship]] program links each sponsor to an individual child in one of the 48 countries where Plan International works. Sponsors contribute money and have an opportunity to correspond with the child and his or her family. Donations are not given directly to the child but are used to support projects for entire communities.[http://www.planusa.org/sponsorachild/sac_landing_index.php/id/1504455/tp/VE1HUj0xLHRpZD0xNTA0NTA1LA%3D%3D How child sponsorship works| www.planusa.org] Along with [[microloans]], direct sponsorship projects have been described to be an option for people interested in contributing to a [[do it yourself]] style of [[foreign aid]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.philanthropy.com/article/Tips-for-Do-It-Yourself/194093/|title=Tips for Do-It-Yourself Foreign Aid|date=Oct 21, 2010|website=The Chronicle of Philanthropy}} ==Board of directors== Plan International USA employs 97 staff and has a separate governing body and Executive Team from Plan International. As of 2010, the members of the board of directors include: {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * Howard Cutler (chairman) * Raj K. Nooyi (vice chair) * Eric Chatman (treasurer) * Dorota Keverian (secretary) * Isobel Coleman, Ph.D. * Paul S. Dwyer, Jr. * Georgiana Gibson, M.D. {{col-2}} * Deborah Held * Ahmed Moen * Jack Poulson * Tamer Rashad * Walter Stone * Oren E. Whyche-Shaw * Allison Knapp Womack {{col-end}} Tessie San Martin, Ph.D. is the current president/CEO. == Notable associations == [[Laurie Metcalf]], actress known for playing "Jackie Harris" on ''[[Roseanne (TV series)|Roseanne]]'', is a spokesperson for Plan International USA and a child sponsor through the organization.{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K_fPIKUEuko|title=YouTube|website=www.youtube.com}} Other notable persons who have publicly given their support for Plan International USA include [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jacqueline Kennedy]], who was honorary chairwoman during Plan's Silver Jubilee, David Elliot, [[Beau Bridges]], [[Dina Eastwood]], [[Scott Bakula]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iK-uYX0WFgY&feature=player_embedded|title=YouTube|website=www.youtube.com}} and [[Nicholas D. Kristof]], also a child sponsor.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/19/opinion/19kristof.html|title=Opinion | Changing Lives, Mitt by Mitt|date=Apr 18, 2009|via=NYTimes.com}} ==In popular culture== The organization was featured in the 2002 film ''[[About Schmidt]].'' ==References== ==External links== * [http://planusa.org Plan International USA website] * [http://www.plan-international.org Plan International website] * [http://yugacentral.blogspot.com/ YUGA blog] * [http://www.planusa.org/researchandreports Plan Research and Reports] {{DEFAULTSORT:Plan (Aid Organisation)}} [[Category:Children's charities based in the United States]] [[Category:Charities based in Rhode Island]] [[Category:International charities]]

{{Infobox company | traded_as = {{nyse|KRA}}
[[S&P 600|S&P 600 Component]] | website = {{URL|kraton.com}}}} '''Kraton''' is the trade name given to a number of high performance [[elastomer]]s manufactured by [[Kraton Polymers]] ({{nyse|KRA}}), and used as [[Chemical synthesis|synthetic]] replacements for [[rubber]]. Kraton polymers offers many of the properties of natural rubber, such as flexibility, high traction, and sealing abilities, but with increased resistance to heat, weathering, and chemicals. It was first made by the chemical division of the [[Shell Oil Company]] in the 1950s,{{cite web|url= http://kraton.com/about/message.php |title=CEO's message |publisher=Kraton Polymers |accessdate=4 November 2012}} under the technical leadership of Murray Luftglass and [[Norman R. Legge]].{{cite book|last1=Hsieh|first1=Henry|last2=Quirk|first2=Rodney|title=Anionic Polymerization: Principles and Practical Applications|date=1996|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9780824795238|page=480|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GEcJJC-dhVsC&pg=PA480&lpg=PA480&dq=kraton+legge&source=bl&ots=YG4Mrocw-2&sig=5yb_nbp_ALBjZpQjCbibAXjhB5U&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiIvLmWu-PVAhWh7IMKHehMAIgQ6AEILDAA#v=onepage&q=kraton%20legge&f=false|accessdate=19 August 2017}} Shell sold its Kraton polymers business to private equity firm [[Ripplewood Holdings]] in March 2001.{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YgR7y6HgYqQC&pg=PA101&dq=Kraton+Polymers |page=101 |title=Polymers for Electronic Components |first=Kieth |last=Cousins |publisher=Rapra Technology |year=2001 |isbn=9781847351982 |accessdate=4 November 2012}} ==Properties== [[File:Sbs block copolymer.jpg|thumb|Sbs block copolymer in [[Transmission electron microscopy|TEM]]]] Kraton polymers are styrenic [[block copolymer]] (SBC) consisting of [[polystyrene]] blocks and rubber blocks. The rubber blocks consist of [[polybutadiene]], [[polyisoprene]] or their hydrogenated equivalents. The tri-block with polystyrene blocks at both extremities linked together by a rubber block is the most important polymer structure observed in SBC. If the rubber block consist of polybutadiene, the corresponding triblock structure is: poly(styrene-block-butadiene-block-styrene) usually abbreviated as SBS. Kraton D (SBS and SIS) and their selectively hydrogenated versions Kraton G (SEBS and SEPS) are the major Kraton polymer structures. The microstructure of SBS consists of domains of polystyrene arranged regularly in a matrix of polybutadiene, as shown in the [[Transmission electron microscopy|TEM]] micrograph. The picture was obtained on a thin film of polymer cast onto [[mercury (element)|mercury]] from solution, and then stained with [[osmium tetroxide]]. The [[glass transition temperature]] (Tg) of the polybutadiene blocks is typically −90°C and Tg of the polystyrene blocks is +100°C. So, at any temperature between about −90°C and +100°C Kraton SBS will act as a physically crosslinked [[elastomer]]. If Kraton polymers are heated substantially above the Tg of the styrene-derived blocks, that is, above about 100°C, like 170°C the physical [[cross-links]] change from rigid [[glass]]y regions to flowable melt regions and the entire material flows and therefore can be cast, molded, or extruded into any desired form. On cooling, this new form resumes its elastomeric character. This is the reason such a material is called a [[thermoplastic elastomer]] (TPE). The polystyrene blocks form domains of [[nanometre]] size in the microstructure, and they stabilise the form of the moulded material. Depending on the rubber to polystyrene ratio in the material, the polystyrene domains can be spherical or form cylinders or [[lamella (materials)|lamella]]e. The hydrogenated Kraton polymers named Kraton G exhibit improved resistance to temperature (processing at 200–230°C is common), to oxidation and to UV. SEBS and SEPS due to their polyolefinic rubber nature present excellent compatibility with polyolefins and paraffinic oils. == Applications == Kraton polymers are always used in blends with various other ingredients like paraffinic oils, polyolefins, polystyrene, bitumen, tackifying resins, fillers to provide a very large range of end-use products ranging from hot melt adhesives to impact modified transparent polypropylene bins, from medical TPE compounds to modified bitumen roofing felts or from oil gel toys (including sex toys) to elastic attachments in diapers. It can make [[asphalt]] flexible, which is necessary if the asphalt is to be used to coat a surface that is below grade or for highly demanding paving applications like F1 racing tracks. Kraton based compounds are also used in non-slip knife handles. [[File:1982 AMC Eagle 4-door wagon two-tone 07.jpg|thumb|Color matched Kraton wheel opening extensions on 1980–88 [[AMC Eagle]]s]] The earliest commercial components using Kraton G (thermoplastic rubber) in the automobile industry were in 1975.{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=LyLKf38zut0C&pg=PT39&dq=Kraton+Polymers+automobile |title=Thermoplastic elastomers II: Processing for performance: Papers from a one-day seminar, Volume 2 |publisher=iSmithers Rapra Technology |year=1989 |isbn=9780902348417 |accessdate=29 January 2017}} [[American Motors]] (AMC) used this polymer plastic on the [[AMC Eagle]] for the color matched flexible wheel arch flares that flowed into rocker panel extensions.{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=r9j7MWLE_jMC&pg=PA270&dq=AMC+Eagle+plastic+polymer+material+Kraton |title=The Cars of American Motors: An Illustrated History |first=Marc|last=Cranswick |publisher=McFarland |year=2012 |page=270 |isbn=978-0-7864-4672-8 |quote=A plastic polymer material bearing the trademark name "Kraton" was used for the wheel well extenders, rocker moldings and lower door panel protectors. |accessdate=29 January 2017}} Some grades of Kraton can also be dissolved into hydrocarbon oils to create "shear thinning" grease type products that are used in the manufacture of telecommunications cables containing optical fibres. ==References== {{Reflist}} * {{cite journal|last=Lewis |first=PR |title=Electron Microscopy of sym-SBS block polymers |journal=Polymer |date=January 1972 |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=20–26 |doi= 10.1016/0032-3861(72)90030-4}} * [http://www.kraton.com/products/Kraton_G_SEBS_SEPS.php Kraton G SEBS and SEPS polymer official data documents and applications], retrieved on 6 May 2017. [[Category:Companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Polymers]] [[Category:Copolymers]] [[Category:Brand name materials]]

'''Dany Toussaint''' was a candidate in the [[2006 Haitian elections|February 2006 presidential election]] in [[Haiti]]. Toussaint is a former [[Haitian Army]] major, police chief and bodyguard of [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]]. He is a former Senator and leader of the [[Haitian Democratic and Reformist Movement Party]].
==Investigation== In 2003, Judge Claudy Gassant requested that Toussaint's immunity from prosecution be lifted in regards to the assassination of Haitian journalist [[Jean Dominique]] who had accused Toussaint of having his rival for the position of Secretary of State for Public Security, Jean Lamy, assassinated. The request of Judge Gassant was rejected by the senate.<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=6197 Reporters Sans Frontières] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5v25oEgZZ?url=http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=6197 |date=December 17, 2010 }}</ref>
==Arrest== On January 2, 2006, [[MINUSTAH]] troops arrested Toussaint for possession of illegal weapons.<ref>http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=122&art_id=qw1136269097787R131</ref> He was handed over to the [[Haitian National Police]], who released him hours later.<ref>[https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=17082&Cr=Haiti&Cr1= Haiti: former Senator detained after UN mission finds illegal weapons] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5v25psLpb?url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=17082&Cr=Haiti&Cr1= |date=December 17, 2010 }}</ref>
==References==
<references /> * [http://www.diacritica.com/sobaka/newswire/2005/09/0910005a.html Haiti: Rogue's Gallery: Dany Toussaint] * The Non-Voter's Guide to the Haitian Presidential Election, Cali Ruchala, ''Sobaka'', September 10, 2005 * [http://www.haitipolicy.org/content/3213.htm Twenty-five Presidential Candidates and Counting] Radio Metropole, August 29, 2005 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051028031746/http://nchr.org/hrp/jando/sound_of_silence.htm The Sound of Silence - Killing the Hope in Haiti], Jean Jean-Pierre, ''Village Voice'' {{2006 presidential election candidates, Haiti}}

[[SABC2]] | first_aired = 1995 (Pilot), 14 November 1997 | last_aired = 31 March 2005 }} '''''Bernard's Watch''''' (informally known as '''''Bernard''''' in the final series) is a British children's drama series about a young boy who could stop time with a magical [[pocket watch]]. The show was created by [[Andrew Norriss]] and was produced for seven series that aired on [[CITV]] from 14 November 1997 to 31 March 2005. ==History== The concept of the show originally formed the basis of one of the most famous episodes of [[The Twilight Zone]], entitled [[A Kind of a Stopwatch]], first broadcast in 1963. In 1991, Alexander John Howard conceived of a series based on the same concept but it took six years to get funding. The show eventually began as a single 15-minute episode, however it was suggested it could work as a series. Four more stories were written by creator [[Andrew Norriss]], who thought, in his own words, "that would be it". However he ended up writing six series. The original series aired from 14 November 1997 to 7 December 2001 and was produced by [[ITV Central|Central Television]]. It was written by Andrew Norris,{{Cite web | url=http://www.andrewnorriss.co.uk | title=The Website of Andrew Norriss}} who wrote the book Bernard's Watch, a novelization based on the first three series, in 1999 which was published by Puffin.{{Cite web | url=http://www.andrewnorriss.co.uk/bernardswatchtv.html | title=Bernard's Watch}}{{Cite web | url=http://www.andrewnorriss.co.uk/bernardswatch.html | title=Bernard's Watch}} It was primarily filmed at [[South Wilford CofE Primary School]], [[Nottingham]]. These series were produced by Lewis Ruddhttps://uk.imdb.com/name/nm0748616 and directed by David Cobham.https://uk.imdb.com/name/nm0167886 A couple of years after its original run, the show was revived for two more series and included a change to the format, new cast and filming location. The first of the new series was produced by [[Carlton Television]] and aired from 6 January to 30 March 2004. The second of the new series and the seventh and final of the show overall, renamed as 'Bernard', was produced by [[Granada Yorkshire]] and aired from 6 January to 31 March 2005. The school scenes were filmed at Kerr Mackie Primary School, [[Leeds]]. ==Synopsis== ===Original series (1997-2001)=== The first run told of a young boy called Bernard, played by David Peachey, from Oakwood, Nottinghamshire, who was always late, until a [[postman]] gave him a "magic watch" which could stop and rewind time. He soon found out that the postman had magical powers, and that these watches were given to people who needed them. The rules of him keeping his watch were that he must not use it to commit crimes or hurt anyone. Every episode focused on Bernard or someone to whom he'd lent the watch facing a problem or simply doing day-to-day things and trying to sort them out, using the watch. ===New series (2004-2005)=== The second run was significantly different. According to the final opening sequence, the watch simply flew through Bernard's window. The character of the "postman" did not exist, and Bernard seemed to be the only person in the world who had such a watch. His best friend Nathan knew about the watch. This series revolved mainly around Bernard's school, Pentup Primary, where he'd usually get the better of his bullying schoolteacher Ms Yvonne Savage and a popular girl called Nicolette. By this series, David Peachey moved on from his portrayal of Bernard; he has since moved on from a career in acting and was studying art in Venice. {{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} ===Novel=== As well as the TV series, Andrew Norris also wrote a novel based on the series in 1999. In the context of the novel, Bernard received the watch from an elderly aunt, who had received it from her husband who got it from an old friend, although they never knew where the friend had acquired the watch as by the time he passed it on he had suffered a stroke and couldn't speak. Unlike in the TV show where using the watch was harmless, the watch has a subtle side-effect on the user in that it uses up the iron in their blood, requiring regular users to consume iron vitamins on a regular basis, causing Bernard to collapse when he avoids taking the iron-tainted drink provided by his aunt because he didn't like the taste and was unaware of the side-effects of the watch. On a personal note, Bernard is only living with his father, as his mother died before the events of the novel, and Karen is also shown as only having one parent. At the novel's conclusion, the watch is briefly stolen by a woman who once worked as a housekeeper for Bernard's aunt, but she is captured when the watch runs down and she tries to threaten Bernard for the key. Ill at various points throughout the book, Bernard's aunt dies in the penultimate chapter, but her spirit appears to him after her death to tell him that the true purpose of the watch is for 'learning'. In the final chapter, Bernard uses the watch key on a chain his aunt gave him to wind it back up, Bernard and Karen enjoying the restoration of the Watch as Bernard concludes that he has time to learn what she meant by that comment. ==Main cast== ===Original series: 1997-2001=== *'''Narrator''' - [[Liza Goddard]] *'''Bernard Beasley''' - David Peachey *'''Postman''' - [[Jack McKenzie (actor)|Jack McKenzie]] *'''Mr John Beasley''' - Martin Neil *'''Mrs Jane Beasley''' - Ruth Hudson *'''Grandad''' - [[Barry Jackson (actor)|Barry Jackson]] *'''Karen Hewitt''' - Phoebe Allen (series 1-3) *'''Nathan Hewitt''' - Patrick Ball (series 1-3) *'''Lucy Rownham''' - Elizabeth Mellor (series 4) *'''Sam Vernon''' - Samantha Birch (series 5) *'''American Postman''' - [[Derek Griffiths]] (series 4) ===New series: 2004-05=== *'''Bernard Beasley''' - [[Ryan Watson (actor)|Ryan Watson]] *'''Robbie''' - Nick Baker *'''Nathan''' - [[Garfield|Patrick Ball]] *'''Nicolette Ashbury''' - [[Rosie Day]] *'''Ms Yvonne Savage''' - Kay Purcell *'''Mr Steel''' - [[Martin Ball]] ==Episodes== {{main article|List of Bernard's Watch episodes}} ==Media Releases== There were several sell-through VHS tapes available of the show, featuring episodes from the first two series, though the publisher has since deleted these. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{tv.com show|bernards-watch}} *{{IMDb title|id=0171980|title=Bernard's Watch}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090706062015/http://www.memorabletv.com/kids_tv_b.htm Bernard's Watch at memorabletv.com] [[Category:1997 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2005 British television programme endings]] [[Category:1990s British children's television series]] [[Category:2000s British children's television series]] [[Category:ITV children's television programmes]] [[Category:Television series by ITV Studios]] [[Category:Television programmes produced by Central Independent Television]] [[Category:Television shows featuring audio description]] [[Category:ITV television dramas]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:British time travel television series]] [[Category:The Den]]

{{Wiktionary|walk the dog}} '''[[Dog walking]]''' is the act of exercising a dog.
'''Dog walking''', '''Dog Walk''', '''Walking the dog''' or '''Walk the dog''' and other variants may also refer to:
* [[Dog Walk, Illinois]], an unincorporated community * [[Dog Walk, Kentucky]], an unincorporated community * ''[[The Dogwalker]]'', a movie directed by Jacques Thelemaque * [[Dogwalker (story)|"Dogwalker" (story)]], a 1990 short story by Orson Scott Card * "[[Walking the Dog]]", a song originally by Rufus Thomas and covered by many artists, including The Rolling Stones * "[[Walkin' the Dog]]", a song written by Shelton Brooks in 1916 * [[Walking the Dog (Gershwin)|''Walking the Dog'' (Gershwin)]], a musical piece by George Gershwin * "Walking The Dog", a song on the 2009 album ''[[Aim and Ignite]]'' by Fun
==See also == *''[[Wag the Dog]]'', a 1997 film

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox Radio Show | show_name = Deep Trouble | image = | imagesize = | caption = | other_names = | format = [[Sitcom]] | runtime = 30 minutes | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = [[English language|English]] | home_station = [[BBC Radio 4]] | syndicates = | television = | starring = [[Jim Field Smith]]
[[Ben Willbond]]
[[Katherine Jakeways]]
[[Miranda Raison]] | creator = | writer = Jim Field Smith
Ben Willbond | producer = [[David Tyler (UK)|David Tyler]] | executive_producer = | narrated = Jonathan Ryland | record_location = | first_aired = 20 October 2005 | last_aired = 31 May 2007 | num_series = 2 | num_episodes = 8 | audio_format = | opentheme = | endtheme = | website = [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/comedy/deeptrouble.shtml BBC Homepage] | podcast = }} '''''Deep Trouble''''' is a [[BBC]] [[radio]] [[comedy]] series, written by and starring [[Jim Field Smith]] and [[Ben Willbond]], which first aired on BBC Radio 4 in October 2005. It takes place in the year 2012, aboard HMS ''Goliath'', a [[Royal Navy]] stealth nuclear [[submarine]], and follows the trials and tribulations of the submarine's chaotic crew, underneath their inept commanding officer, Captain Paul Wade (played by [[Jim Field Smith]]) and his officers Lieutenant Trainor, Weapons Officer (played by [[Ben Willbond]]), Commander Alison Fairbanks, second-in-command (played by [[Katherine Jakeways]]). The series has also included a fourth regular character - in season one only this was Petty Officer Lucy Radcliffe (played by [[Miranda Raison]]) and in season two this was Alice Barry, Computer and Weapons Expert (played by [[Alice Lowe]]). The series parodies several features of the submarine genre established by ''[[The Hunt for Red October (film)|The Hunt for Red October]]'' and ''[[Crimson Tide (film)|Crimson Tide]]'' and as such its announcer is a version of [[Tom Clancy]]. Series One started on Thursday 20 October 2005, and the series contains four episodes in total: "Startled Deer", "Special Relationship", "Prize Hamper", and "Crispy Duck". Series Two started on Thursday 24 May 2007. Writing for ''[[The Times]]'', Chris Campling compared the programme favourably to the famous Naval radio sitcom ''[[The Navy Lark]]'' and called ''Deep Trouble'' "hilarious".{{cite news |title= Radio head |author= Chris Campling |url= http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article1794502.ece |newspaper= The Times |date= 19 May 2007 |accessdate=19 February 2011}} It was also selected as a 'Pick of the Day' by Phil Daoust of [[the Guardian]] on 24 May 2007.{{cite news |title= Pick of the day |author= Phil Daoust |url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/may/24/tvandradio.radio |newspaper= The Guardian |date= 24 May 2007 |accessdate=19 February 2011}} The series was produced and directed by [[David Tyler (UK)|David Tyler]] at [[Pozzitive Television]] for [[BBC Radio 4]]. ==Cast== *[[Katy Brand]] *[[Jim Field Smith]] - Wade *[[Steve Furst]] *[[Boris Isarov]] *[[Katherine Jakeways]] - Fairbanks *[[Rufus Jones (actor)|Rufus Jones]] *[[Miranda Raison]] - Radcliffe (series 1 only) *[[Jonathan Ryland]] - narrator *[[Kerry Shale]] *[[Renton Skinner]] *[[Gareth Tunley]] *[[Ben Willbond]] - Trainor *[[Alice Lowe]] - Barry (series 2 only) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{BBC Online|radio4/comedy/deeptrouble.shtml|''Deep Trouble''}} *{{Epguides|DeepTrouble|Deep Trouble}} *{{British Comedy Guide|radio|deep_trouble|Deep Trouble}} [[Category:BBC Radio comedy programmes]] [[Category:2005 radio programme debuts]] [[Category:BBC Radio 4 programmes]] [[Category:Fiction set in 2012]]

revision.comment: Add: date. Removed accessdate with no specified URL. | You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]].| Activated by [[User:Chris Capoccia]] | [[Category:Pages using citations with accessdate and no URL]].
revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = V.P. Menon |image = V. P. Menon.jpg |caption = |birth_name = Vappala Pangunni Menon |birth_date = {{Birth date|1893|09|30|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Ottapalam]], [[Madras Presidency]], [[British India|British Raj]] (Present day [[Kerala]]) |death_date = {{Death date and age|1965|12|31|1893|09|30|df=yes}}, [[Bangalore]] |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = Civil servant |nationality = Indian }} [[Rao Bahadur]] '''Vappala Pangunni Menon''', [[Order of the Star of India|CSI]], [[Order of the Indian Empire|CIE]] (30 September 1893 – 31 December 1965) was an Indian [[civil servant]] who was the Constitutional Adviser<ref name="VP Menon">{{cite news |url=http://www.forgotten-raj.org/doc/vp6.pdf |title=V P Menon – The Forgotten Architect of Modern India |work=Forgotten Raj |date=13 April 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726061929/http://www.forgotten-raj.org/doc/vp6.pdf |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="VP Menon Architect">{{cite news |url=http://www.britishempire.co.uk/maproom/india/vpmenon.htm |title=V P Menon – The Forgotten Architect of Modern India |work= |date= |accessdate=18 September 2014}}</ref> and Political Reforms Commissioner to the last three Viceroys during British rule in India.
He played a vital role in India's [[partition of India|partition]] and [[Political integration of India|political integration]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/research/how-vallabhbhai-patel-v-p-menon-and-mountbatten-unified-india-4915468/|title=How Vallabhbhai Patel, V P Menon and Mountbatten unified India|date=31 October 2017}}</ref> Later in his life, he became a member of the free-market–oriented [[Swatantra Party]].
==Personal life== The son of a school headmaster in [[Kerala]], Menon worked as a railway stoker, coal miner and Bangalore tobacco company clerk before gaining a junior post in the Indian Civil Service. By working assiduously, Menon rose through the ranks to become the highest serving Indian officer in [[British India]]. In 1946, he was appointed Political Reforms Commissioner to the British Viceroy.
In [[Patrick French]]'s ''India: A Portrait'', a biographical book on the Indian Subcontinent, it is mentioned that VP Menon moved in with his Keralite friends after his wife left him and returned to south India. The two friends, who were a couple, had arranged his marriage and helped raise his two sons – Pangunni Anantan Menon and Pangunni Shankaran Menon. When the husband died, Menon married his widow.<ref>India - a portrait by Patrick French - page 13</ref>
Menon was given the title of ''[[Rao Bahadur]]'', appointed a [[Order of the Indian Empire|CIE]] in the 1941 Birthday Honours <ref>[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/35184/supplements/3285 London Gazette, 6 June 1941]</ref> and a [[Order of the Star of India|CSI]] in the 1946 Birthday Honours.<ref>[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/37598/supplements/2760 London Gazette, 13 June 1946]</ref>
==Partition of India== :''See Also: [[Indian Independence Movement]], [[Partition of India]]''
Menon was the political advisor of the last [[Viceroy of India]], Lord [[Louis Mountbatten]]. When the interim Government had collapsed due to the rivalry between the [[Indian National Congress]] and the [[All-India Muslim League|Muslim League]], Menon had proposed to Mountbatten, [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] and [[Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel]], the Indian leaders, the Muslim League's plan to partition India into two independent nations - India and [[Pakistan]].
Menon's resourcefulness during this period caught the eye of Sardar Patel, who would become the [[Deputy Prime Minister of India]] in 1947.
VP Menon was present at the meeting between Lord Mountbatten and [[Hanwant Singh]], Maharaja of [[Jodhpur]]. It was at this meeting that Hanwant Singh signed the instrument of accession to India. After he had signed and the Viceroy Mountbatten left, only Menon was in the room with him. The Maharaja took out a .22 calibre pistol and pointed it at Menon and said 'I refuse to take your dictation'. Menon told him that he would be making a very serious mistake by threatening him and would not be able to get the accession abrogated in any case.<ref>India - a portrait by Patrick French (page 10)</ref>
==Integration of India== {{main|Political Integration of India}}
After the independence of India, Menon became the secretary of the Ministry of the States, headed by [[Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel]], with whom he had developed a bond of trust. Patel respected Menon's political genius and work ethic, while Menon obtained the respect for his work that a civil servant needs from his political superior.
Menon worked closely with Patel over the integration of over 565 [[princely state]]s into the [[union of India]], managing the diplomacy between the States Ministry and the various Indian princes, acting as Patel's envoy and striking deals with reluctant princes and rulers. Patel respected Menon's ingenuity in diplomacy, and often did not question if Menon exceeded any instructions.
Menon also worked with Patel over the military action against the hostile states of [[Junagadh]] and [[Hyderabad state|Hyderabad]], as well as advising Nehru and Patel on relations with [[Pakistan]] and the [[History of the Kashmir conflict|Kashmir conflict]]. The Cabinet had dispatched Menon to obtain the accession of [[Kashmir]] into India in 1947.
At Sardar Patel's behest, Menon subsequently wrote a book "The story of the integration of the Indian states" describing the process they had adopted for each state, based on his first hand experiences of the process.<ref name="menon">{{cite book |last1=Menon |first1=V.P. |title=The story of the integration of the Indian states |date=15 September 1955 |publisher=Longman Greens and Co |location=Bangalore }}</ref><ref name="bjpcopy">{{cite web |last1=Menon |first1=V.P. |title=Pdf copy of the book "The Story of the Integration of the Indian States" |url=http://lib.bjplibrary.org/jspui/bitstream/123456789/132/1/V.P.Menon%20-%20Integration%20of%20Princely%20States.pdf |website=BJP E-Library |publisher=Bharatiya Janata Party |accessdate=22 March 2019}}</ref>
==Later years==
The partnership between Patel and Menon was of a rare kind. He was right hand of Sardar Patel and played a major role in integration of Independent India. Almost every Indian politician was allergic to civil servants{{citation needed|date=May 2019}}, owing to their participation in the [[British Raj]]. Many Congressmen had demanded stripping the service of its privileges or disbanding it all together, owing to the role of British-era officers in imprisoning Congress leaders{{citation needed|date=May 2019}}. Nehru himself was reluctant to listen to the civil servants who worked under him{{citation needed|date=May 2019}}. He was [[Governor of Odisha]] (''Orissa then'') for a short period in 1951. Thus, after Patel's death in 1950, Menon himself retired from the newly formed [[Indian Administrative Service]]. He authored a book on the [[political integration of India]], ''The Story of the Integration of Indian States'' and on the [[partition of India]], ''Transfer of Power''. He later joined [[Swatantra Party]]
==Artistic depictions of V.P.Menon== In 2013, [[Adi Irani]] played V. P. Menon in ''[[Pradhanmantri (TV Series)]]'' on [[ABP News]].
==Bibliography== * Menon, V.P (1961), ''The story of the integration of the Indian States'', Orient Longmans, ISBN ASIN: B0007ILF54 * Menon, V.P (1999), ''Integration of Indian States'', Sangam Books Ltd, {{ISBN|81-250-1597-3}} * Menon, V.P (1999), ''The Transfer of Power in India'', Sangam Books Ltd, {{ISBN|81-250-1596-5}} * V P Menon - The Forgotten Architect of Modern India ([http://www.forgotten-raj.org Forgotten-raj.org])
==See also== * [[Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel]] * [[Partition of India]], [[History of India]] * [[Indian Independence Movement]] * ''Patel: A Life'' by [[Rajmohan Gandhi]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|V. P. Menon}} * [http://www.oxforddnb.com/index/101034986/ [[Walter John Christie|W. H. J. Christie]], ''Menon, Vapal Pangunni (1894–1966)'', rev. S. R. Ashton Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]
{{Indian independence movement}}
{{Authority control}}

:''The following discussion is an archived debate of the proposed deletion of the article below. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page. '' The result of the debate was '''relisting.''' [[User:Woohookitty|''Woohookitty'']][[User talk:Woohookitty|(cat scratches)]] 09:59, 6 November 2005 (UTC) ===[[TeamXbox]]=== Article about the goings-on in the forums of an Xbox365 fansite. In July it was tagged as a speedy and deleted four times, but the entry had virtually no content at that time. --[[User:Anetode|anetode]][[User_talk:Anetode|¹]] [[Special:Contributions/Anetode|²]] [[3 (disambiguation)|³]] 18:06, 31 October 2005 (UTC) * As written, '''delete''', but the site seems pretty notable. [http://forum.teamxbox.com/ According to the site], Threads: 265,611, Posts: 5,029,307, Members: 95,230. --[[User:Howcheng|howcheng]] [ [[User talk:Howcheng|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Howcheng|contribs]] • [http://www.howcheng.com/ web] ] 16:58, 1 November 2005 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Kraton (polymer)]]
#REDIRECT [[Hassagers Kollegium]] {{R from other capitalisation}}

===[[H5N1]]===
A successful [[WP:AID]] article, I think this is of great significance just now. -[[User:Litefantastic|Litefantastic]] 18:07, 31 October 2005 (UTC)
Someone should convert all of the external links that are in the body of the article into numbered references. At the very least, people have to stop inserting new external links that disrupt the existing numbered references. --[[User:JWSchmidt|JWSchmidt]] 18:18, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Comment''': Is this really stable? [[User:KingTT|KingTT]] 19:46, 31 October 2005 (UTC)
*'''Object''', the following need to be addressed: #The lead needs to mention why H5N1 is a concern. #html links should be converted to footnotes and full details of source included (this seems to be in progress) #By my understanding 2004/05 isn't the first time HN51 has been recorded, can some information on the first occurence and subsequent identificaion of the virus be added. #The Asia and beyond section reads like the current events page, please try and incorporte this information into cohesive paragraphs. #Merge pig cases and big cat cases into a sectional called HN51 in other animals. #The worst case scenario section should probably be L2 heading and notably this is the only unsourced section, it would be useful for the reader to know which agencies are concerned about a pandemic. Information on planning for a pandemic and government responses would also be valuable addtions. #Remove see alsos that are already mentioed in the text. --[[User:Petaholmes|nixie]] 23:49, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Comment''' the cleanup taskforce have been looking at this and have yet to decide it is "clean" - I don't know what that means but we should remember that. [[User:Andreww|Andreww]] 09:16, 1 November 2005 (UTC) *'''Object''', just looking at the lead section: # Third paragraph. "Usually these flu viruses " which flu viruses - N5H1 or bird flu in general? The Spanish flu was H1N1 so I guess bird flu in general but it's not clear. # Is this about one particular H5N1 virus or about H5N1 viruses in general? I think H5N1 existed before 1997 but it only became so dangerous then. [[User:Andreww|Andreww]] 09:24, 1 November 2005 (UTC) * '''Support''': extensive, thorough, very well researched, structured and illustrated, this is the quintessential featured article. Furthermore, it is currently of high relevance and interest and will attract kudos and lots of traffic to Wikipedia once again. I suggest we focus on this one for rapid approval. --[[User:Rsabbatini|R.Sabbatini]] 10:28, 7 November 2005 (UTC) *'''Strong object''' Will not meet stability criterion until the current scare goes away. Has many short subsections and paragraphs. Inline external links should probably be converted to footnotes. The "Asia and beyond" section is far from being brilliant prose. Poor layout by the end of the article. "Worst case scenario section" should be ''far'' longer and include current research. There is absolutely ''no info'' on the 1997 outbreak beyond a passing mention on the lead... and the list goes on. -- [[User:Rune.welsh|Rune Welsh]] | [[User_talk:Rune.welsh|ταλκ]] | [[Wikipedia:Esperanza|<font color="#339900">Esperanza</font>]] 02:46, 8 November 2005 (UTC) *'''Support''' I have this page on my watchlist and I haven't seen any stability problems at all, there doesn't seem to be any sort of popularity of the article among vandals, and there don't seem to be any edit wars due to content disputes. But I don't think it matters, shouldn't this of been closed months ago? [[User:Homestarmy|Homestarmy]] 15:40, 26 March 2006 (UTC) *'''Comment''': #Infobox should be at the top of the article, instead of pushed down by an image. #Image #1841 (the colorized transmission electron micrograph of H5N1) is displayed twice, this is redundant. #The Wikinews template seems to be placed in an odd section in the middle of the article. --[[User:Hetar|Hetar]] 03:20, 6 April 2006 (UTC) *'''Comment''': As Hetar pointed out, [[H5N1]] is a regular hotbed of dispute over where to place images. In no way ready for Featured Article status. Move on, nothing to see here. [[User:WAS 4.250|WAS 4.250]] 04:53, 6 April 2006 (UTC) *'''Comment.''' I have delisted this nomination. It seems to be a mix of several old noms--look at the dates of the comments! Please follow the instructions for re-nominations at the top of [[WP:FAC]]. Move any old noms to archives (separate archives!). Start the new nom from scratch with a new header (not one dated October 2005), which contains links to these archives, and without any old comments, and post it at the top (not the foot) of [[WP:FAC]]. I'm sorry, I'm not trying to be difficult, but a nomination that conflates at least three different discussions just won't work. And how about the comments from April 6 (day before yesterday..?) Don't just put this back, please. [[User:Bishonen|Bishonen]] | [[User talk:Bishonen|talk]] 18:54, 8 April 2006 (UTC). *'''Comment.''' Since this is a [[WP:GACo]], I suggest holding this off till monday when it'll be rotated out. I'll re-nominate it at that point myself if no one else has. (I think that most if not all of the above objections have been adressed either before, or during the improvement drive.) --[[User:Barberio|Barberio]] 19:57, 8 April 2006 (UTC)

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta15)
revision.text:
{{Infobox hotel | hotel_name = Delta Hotels Bessborough | former_names = The Bessborough | highest_region = [[List of tallest buildings in Saskatoon|Saskatoon]] | highest_start = 1932 | highest_end = 1966 | highest_prev = [[Canada Building (Saskatoon)|Canada Building]] | highest_next = Marquis Tower | developer = [[Canadian National Railway]] | architectural_style= [[Châteauesque]] | groundbreaking_date= 1930 | opened_date = 10 December 1935 | floors = 10 | namesake = [[Vere Ponsonby, 9th Earl of Bessborough|9th Earl of Bessborough]] | height = {{convert|58.5|m|ft}} | image = Hotel Bessborough 2011.jpg | caption = The Delta Bessborough | location = {{nowrap|601 Spadina Crescent East}}
[[Saskatoon]], [[Saskatchewan]]
S7K 3G8 | coordinates = {{coord|52|07|35|N|106|39|33|W|scale:5000_region:CA_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | architect = [[Archibald and Schofield]]{{cite web | url = http://dictionaryofarchitectsincanada.org/architects/view/55 | title = Archibald, John Smith | work = Biographical Dictionary of Architects in Canada 1800-1950 | accessdate = 10 September 2011}} | operator = [[Delta Hotels]] | owner = [[Marriott International]] | number_of_restaurants = 3 | number_of_rooms = 225 | website = {{URL|http://www.marriott.com/hotels/travel/yxedb-delta-hotels-bessborough/}} | footnotes = {{emporis|124278}}{{skyscraperpage|15642}}{{structurae|s20040472}} }} The '''Delta Hotels Bessborough''', formerly and commonly known as '''The Bessborough''', is a historic hotel located in [[Saskatoon]], [[Saskatchewan]], Canada. The hotel is situated within the [[Central Business District, Saskatoon|Central Business District]], a commercial district in the Saskatoon. The Bessborough was designed by [[Archibald and Schofield]] for [[Canadian National Hotels]], a division of [[Canadian National Railway]]. Opened in 1935, the [[Châteauesque]]-styled building is {{convert|58.5|m|ft|adj=mid|-tall}}, containing 10 floors. The building is considered one of [[Canada's grand railway hotels]]. After its completion, the building was the [[List of tallest buildings in Saskatoon|tallest building in Saskatoon]], until the nearby Marquis Tower was completed in 1966. The hotel is presently managed by [[Marriott International]] and is owned by [[Leadon Operations LP]]. ==Location== [[File:Delta Bessborough, Spadina Cres E, Saskatoon (505715) (26106545836).jpg|thumb|left|The Delta Bessborough is situated near the [[South Saskatchewan River]].]] The Delta Bessborough is located at 601 Spadina Crescent East at the southeastern end of the [[Central Business District, Saskatoon|Central Business District]], the commercial centre of Saskatoon. The hotel property is bounded by a roadway, and a natural waterway, and parkland. To the east of the hotel lies the [[South Saskatchewan River]], a major waterway that runs through the city. The property is bounded to the north and south by Kiwanis Park, with the property bisecting the park into two areas. To the west, the hotel is bounded by Spadina Crescent East. The hotel is the eastern [[terminating vista]] for 21st Street East, and the view terminus on Spadina Crescent from points south of the hotel. The hotel is situated near a number of attractions located within the Central Business District. Southwest of the hotel lies a [[performing arts centre]], the [[Remai Arts Centre]], and an [[art gallery]], [[Remai Modern]]. Situated northwest of the hotel is [[Midtown Plaza (Saskatoon)|Midtown Plaza]] shopping centre, and a convention centre, [[TCU Place]]. [[Broadway Bridge (Saskatoon)|Broadway Bridge]], an [[arch bridge]] over the South Saskatchewan River, is located south of the hotel. [[Saskatoon station (Canadian Pacific Railway)|Saskatoon station]], a former railway station and a [[National Historic Sites of Canada|National Historic Site of Canada]] is located northwest of the hotel, just outside the Central Business District. ==Design== ===Architecture=== [[File:Delta Bessborough, Spadina Cres E, Saskatoon (505740) (25582348664).jpg|left|thumb|The interior of the hotel features ceiling moulds, and plaster relifs.]] The Delta Bessborough is one of [[Canada's grand railway hotels]] built for [[Canadian National Railway]]. The hotel was initially designed [[Archibald and Schofield|John S. Archibald]], although John Schofield would take over after Archibald's death.{{cite book|title=Rails Across the Prairies: The Railway Heritage of Canada's Prairie Provinces|last=Brown|first=Ron|publisher=Dundurn|year=2012|pages=101–102|isbn=1-4597-0215-8}} The building was designed in a [[Châteauesque]]-style, with further inspiration drawn from castles in [[Bavaria]].{{cite web|title=Delta Bessborough Hotel - Saskatoon Tour Guide|publisher=Saskatoon Kiosk|url=http://www.saskatoonkiosk.ca/saskatoon-tour/Delta-Bessborough-Hotel.php|accessdate=13 January 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221120531/http://www.saskatoonkiosk.ca/saskatoon-tour/Delta-Bessborough-Hotel.php|archive-date=21 December 2008|dead-url=yes}} The heavy use of the Châteauesque architectural style on a number of early grand railway hotels in the country eventually led to its recognition as a distinct Canadian architectural style by the 1920s.{{cite book|title=The Railway Hotels and the Development of the Château Style in Canada|publisher=University of Victoria Maltwood Museum|year=1968|last=Kalman|first=Harold D.|pages=11–12}} In an effort to capitalize on this sentiment, the designs for the hotel were made to emphasize its Châteauesque features, through the increased use of medieval elements. Châteauesque features found on the hotel include [[oriel window]]s, rounded [[turret]]s, [[quoin]]s, [[Course (architecture)|string course]]s, and [[machicolation]]s on the hotel's walls. The roof of the hotel features [[Gothic Revival]] [[dormer]]s with carved [[Tympanum (architecture)|tympana]] are spread throughout. A variety of different [[grotesque]] are also spread throughout the building.{{cite web|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4401664/gargoyles-grotesques-saskatoon/|title=Exploring gargoyles and grotesques in Saskatoon|first=Fiona|last=Odlum|date=22 August 2018|accessdate=26 September 2018|work=Global News|publisher=Corus Entertainment Inc.}} Materials used in construction were of Canadian origin, including Tyndall stone from [[Manitoba]], brick from the [[Claybank Brick Plant]] in [[Claybank, Saskatchewan]], and tiles from [[Estevan, Saskatchewan]].{{cite web|url=http://doorsopensaskatoon.com/downtown.html#bess|title=Downtown Neighbourdhood Buildings|work=Doors Open Saskatoon|date=2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110204100419/http://doorsopensaskatoon.com/downtown.html|archivedate=4 February 2011}} The interior of the hotel features ceiling moulds, plaster [[reliefs]], and [[terrazzo]] floors. ===Facilities=== The hotel includes 225 guest rooms and [[suite (hotel)|suites]]. Suites at the hotel includes the ''Vice Regal Suite'', a suite located on the third floor of the hotel, facing towards the Central Business District. Several areas in the hotel are occupied by three restaurants and other food-based services. Restaurants located within the Bessborough Hotel include the a [[Japanese cuisine|Japanese]] restaurant known as ''Samurai'', and ''Garden Court Cafe'', a restaurant featuring locally sourced food.{{cite web|url=https://thestarphoenix.com/news/delta-bessborough-hotel|title=Delta Bessborough Hotel|work=Saskatoon Star Phoenix|publisher=Postmedia Network Inc.|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=26 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatoon/bess-new-chef-darren-craddock-1.4145302|work=CBC News|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=26 September 2018|date=4 June 2017|first=Alex|last=Soloducha|title=New chef takes sport in one of Saskatoon's top kitchens}} In addition to food-services and lodgings, the hotel also includes a fitness centre, pool, and a {{convert|167|m2|sqft}} spa. The hotel also features {{convert|1672|m2|sqft|round=5}} of event space, used for conferences, weddings, and other social events. The hotel property also features a {{convert|20000|m2|acre|round=5}} of private waterfront gardens backing into the South Saskatchewan River. The gardens hosts large functions and are commonly used a number of social events, most notably the [[Saskatchewan Jazz Festival]]. ==History== [[File:Bessborough Construction.jpg|thumb|The hotel under construction in 1931.]] After the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] built a railway hotel in Regina in 1926, the Saskatoon business community lobbied [[Canadian National Railway]] to build one in [[Saskatoon]]. On December 31, 1928, Sir Henry Thorton, President of the Canadian National Railway, announced that it would build a similar hotel in Saskatoon. In February, 1930, the excavation of the site began using a steam thawer and gasoline excavator. In exchange for building a "chateau" style hotel with a minimum of 200 rooms, the city exempted the railway from [[property tax]] on the hotel for 25 years.{{citation|mode=cs1|chapter-url=http://www.qp.gov.sk.ca/documents/english/private/acts/PR-S66.PDF|chapter=An Act to confirm a certain Byllaw of the City of Saskatoon and a certain Agreement entered into between Canadian Northern Railway Company and the Canadian National Railway Company of the one part and The City of Saskatoon of the other part and for the other purposes being a private act|title=Statutes of Saskatchewan|chapter-format=PDF|date=27 March 1930|accessdate=1 April 2014}} On May 30, 1931, Walter Pratt, General Manager of Hotels, Sleeping and Dining Cars of the Canadian National Railway, announced that [[Excellency|His Excellency]] [[Vere Ponsonby, 9th Earl of Bessborough|The 9th Earl of Bessborough]], 14th [[Governor General of Canada]], had given his consent for the hotel to be formally named "The Bessborough." The Earl and the Countess visited the hotel under construction in 1932. Construction was completed in 1932 but the difficult financial times of the [[Great Depression in Canada|Great Depression]] prevented the hotel from opening until Horace N. Stovin became the first official registered guest, on December 10, 1935. In 1972, Donald, Dick, and [[Marc Baltzan]] purchased the Bessborough. Then, [[Canadian Pacific Hotels]] purchased [[Canadian National Hotels]] in 1982. The Bessborough was placed under CP Hotels' subsidiary [[Delta Hotels]] in the 1990s. In 1999, CP Hotels and Delta Hotels were placed under [[Fairmont Hotels and Resorts]]. It was acquired by the [[Legacy Hotels Real Estate Investment Trust]] in 1998, and in 1999, a $9,000,000 restoration of the Bessborough Hotel was completed to return many of its historical features. The hotel underwent a major renovation in 2003.{{cite web|title=Delta Bessborough|publisher=Frommer's|url=http://www.frommers.com/destinations/saskatoon/H45644.html|accessdate=13 January 2009}} It remains under the [[Delta Hotels]] banner and is now owned by [[Marriott International]]. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons}} *{{Official website|http://www.marriott.com/hotels/travel/yxedb-delta-hotels-bessborough/}} {{Canada's railway hotels}} [[Category:Canadian National Railway hotels]] [[Category:Hotels in Saskatchewan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Saskatoon]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1932]] [[Category:Canadian Pacific Railway hotels]] [[Category:Fairmont Hotels and Resorts]] [[Category:Châteauesque architecture in Canada]] [[Category:Hotels established in 1935]] [[Category:Terminating vistas in Canada]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Saskatoon]] [[Category:1935 establishments in Saskatchewan]]

revision.comment: /* Directing career */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[DreamWorks]] → [[DreamWorks Pictures|DreamWorks]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | image = JFS-stag-2016.jpg | caption = Jim Field Smith on the set of STAG (BBC, 2016) | name = Jim Field Smith | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|2|20|df=yes}} | birth_place = | ethnicity = | education = [[Wellington College, Berkshire]]
[[University of Birmingham]] | occupation = Director, film producer, writer, actor | nationality = British | genre = Comedy | period = 2003–present | notableworks = ''[[Episodes (TV series)|Episodes]]''
''[[The Wrong Mans (UK TV series)|The Wrong Mans]]''
''[[She's Out of My League]]''
''[[Stag (miniseries)|Stag]]'' | spouse = | partner = | influences = | influenced = | website = {{URL|http://www.jimfieldsmith.com}} }} '''Jim Field Smith''' (born 20 February 1979) is an English film and television director, writer and producer. ==Early career== Smith was a member of the British [[sketch comedy]] group [[Dutch Elm Conservatoire]], who were nominated for the prestigious [[Perrier Award]] for their show ''Conspiracy'' in August 2005. The show transferred to the West End, and toured the UK. The following year, the group returned for a third year to the Edinburgh fringe and subsequently the [[Belfast]] theatre festival with a show entitled ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928060421/http://www.dutchelm.co.uk/prison "Prison"]''. He co-wrote and starred in the BBC Radio 4 comedy series ''[[Deep Trouble (radio comedy series)|Deep Trouble]] ''with [[Ben Willbond]]. As an actor, he appeared in various British TV comedies such as Coupling, Snuffbox and My Life in Film, and numerous commercials both on screen and as a voiceover artist. He also wrote several episodes of the MTV puppet sitcom "[[Fur TV]]".{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} ==Directing career== Smith got his break in Hollywood through directing [[short film]]s such as ''Where Have I Been All Your Life?'' (2007) and ''Goodbye to the Normals'' (2006).[http://www.rsafilms.com/company/rsa-uk/director/jim-field-smith Official biography at RSA Films] In [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] in 2008, he directed [[Jay Baruchel]] and [[Alice Eve]] in his first full-length feature, the [[DreamWorks Pictures|DreamWorks]] romantic comedy ''[[She's Out of My League]]'', released worldwide by [[Paramount Pictures]] in 2010. Smith directed ''[[Butter (2011 film)|Butter]]'', a satirical comedy written by Jason Micallef surrounding an Iowan butter sculpting championship, starring [[Jennifer Garner]], [[Hugh Jackman]], [[Olivia Wilde]], and [[Ty Burrell]] that was released in 2011.[http://www.movieline.com/2010/03/exclusive-butter-finds-its-obama-to-go-up-against-jennifer-garners-hillary.php Movieline] He directed the second season of ''[[Episodes (TV series)|Episodes]]'' for [[BBC]] and [[Showtime Networks|Showtime]], starring [[Matt LeBlanc]], gaining [[BAFTA]] and [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe]] nominations for "Best Comedy". Smith is the director/producer of the 2013 [[BBC Two]] comedy-thriller ''[[The Wrong Mans (UK TV series)|The Wrong Mans]]'', written by [[James Corden]], [[Mathew Baynton]] and [[Tom Basden]]. The show, a co-production between [[BBC]] and [[Hulu]], is about a pair of lowly office workers who become unwittingly embroiled in a deadly criminal conspiracy.[http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/the_wrong_mans/details/ Comedy.co.uk] Smith directed, co-wrote and co-produced the 2016 BBC Two comedy-thriller ''[[Stag (miniseries)|Stag]]''. The series, set in the Scottish Highlands, is about a group of young men on a stag weekend and their fight to escape a mystery killer.{{cite web|title=BBC Two - Stag - Credits|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b073gz3n/credits|website=BBC Two - Stag - Credits|publisher=BBC|accessdate=12 March 2016}} He has directed a number of commercials, including campaigns for Cow & Gate, Heinz, Burger King, Smirnoff and MINI. Smith is the co-founder of [[Idiotlamp Productions]], a film and TV production company he established with old school friend and collaborator [http://www.curtisbrown.co.uk/george-kay/ George Kay]. He is represented by production company Little Minx.{{Cite web|url=https://www.adforum.com/agency/4821/creative-work/34541491/the-traffic-jam/grammys|title="The Traffic Jam " for Grammys (by TBWA\CHIAT\DAY LOS ANGELES)|last=States|first=TBWA\CHIAT\DAY LOS ANGELES United|website=AdForum.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-06}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.jimfieldsmith.com/}} *{{IMDb name|1637768}} *[http://www.idiotlamp.com/ Idiotlamp Productions Ltd] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Field Smith, Jim}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:English male radio actors]] [[Category:People educated at Wellington College, Berkshire]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Birmingham]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:English television writers]] [[Category:English film directors]] [[Category:English male writers]] [[Category:Male screenwriters]] [[Category:Male television writers]]
