{{use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{use Canadian English|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox building | name = The Westin Nova Scotian | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = File:Westin Halifax.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = Entrance to The Westin Nova Scotian | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_size = | map_dot_label = | relief = | former_names = Hotel Nova Scotian | alternate_names = | etymology = | status = | building_type = Hotel | architectural_style = | classification = | location = 1181 Hollis Street
[[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]]
B3H 2P6 | coordinates = | altitude = | current_tenants = | namesake = | start_date = 1928 | opened_date = 1930 | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = New Castle Hotels and Resorts | height = | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | top_floor = | other_dimensions = | structural_system = | material = | size = | floor_count = 15 | floor_area = | elevator_count = | grounds_area = | architect = [[Archibald and Schofield]] | developer = [[Canadian National Hotels]] | awards = | designations = | known_for = | parking = | website = {{URL|thewestinnovascotian.com/}} | embed = | embedded = | hotel_chain = | affiliation = [[Westin Hotels & Resorts]] | number_of_rooms = 310 (including suites) | number_of_suites = 10 | number_of_restaurants = | number_of_bars = | facilities = | references = | footnotes = }} '''The Westin Nova Scotian''' is a Canadian hotel located in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]], owned and operated by New Castle Hotels and Resorts. It was built in 1928 by the [[Canadian National Railway]] as the Nova Scotian Hotel and after several changes of owners and names in the late 20th century became the Westin Nova Scotian in 1996. The hotel has been called Halifax's "grande dame" and has played host to numerous dignitaries, royalty, and celebrities over 85 years of existence. ==History== [[File:Pier21in1934.jpg|thumb|left|The Nova Scotian Hotel in 1934 with the [[RMS Majestic (1914)|RMS ''Majestic'']] docked at [[Pier 21]] on the left and the Halifax Railway Station on the right.]] The hotel was built by the [[Canadian National Railways]]. Construction began in 1928 and it opened on 23 June 1930 as the '''Nova Scotian Hotel'''. The hotel was the final part of the [[Halifax, Nova Scotia railway station#South End terminal project|South End terminal project]] which had seen the new [[Halifax, Nova Scotia railway station|Halifax Railway Station]] moved from the north end to the south end of [[Barrington Street]] as well as the opening of the Halifax Ocean Terminal, which included [[Pier 21]], a trans-Atlantic Ocean liner passenger terminal. The hotel was directly connected by an interior walkway to the Halifax Railway Station and by an overhead walkway to Pier 21. The hotel, like others opened by [[Canadian National Hotels]], was designed by [[Archibald and Schofield]], comprising the Canadian architects John Smith Archibald and John Schofield. It was designed as a complex with the [[Halifax, Nova Scotia railway station|Halifax railway station]] and the Cornwallis Park across the street. The central axis of the park is aligned with the front entrance of the Nova Scotian.{{cite web|last1=Ziobrowski|first1=Peter|title=Grand Entries - The Hotel Nova Scotian and the CN Train Station|url=http://halifaxbloggers.ca/builthalifax/2015/02/grand-entries-the-hotel-nova-scotia-and-the-cn-train-station/|publisher=BuiltHalifax.ca|date=17 February 2015}} The hotel had 130 rooms and five suites over eight storeys. The Atlantic Ballroom could accommodate up to 275 dinner guests. A new wing was built to the north in 1959, adding 161 more rooms including nine more suites. In 1966, the name was changed to the '''Hotel Nova Scotian'''. [[Elizabeth II]], Queen of Canada has stayed in the hotel twice, once in the 1950s and once in the 1970s.{{cite web|title=The Westin Nova Scotian Celebrates 85th Anniversary|url=http://assets.thewestinnovascotian.com/lps/assets/u/The-Westin-Nova-Scotian-Celebrates-85th-Anniversary-1.pdf|publisher=Westin Nova Scotian|accessdate=28 June 2015}} [[Prince Charles]] and [[Princess Diana]] attended a state dinner on 15 June 1983 at the Hotel Nova Scotian hosted by Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]]. The 700 guests enjoyed a dinner of Canadian wines and cuisine and Trudeau told the Royal couple they had begun their visit in "the most friendly part of Canada." A crowd of thousands grew outside the hotel hoping to catch a glimpse of the couple before they returned to the [[HMY Britannia|HMY ''Britannia'']] for their departure from Halifax.{{cite news|last1=Harris|first1=Michael|title=Crowd cheers Princess and PM|work=The Globe and Mail|date=16 June 1983|page=1}} The hotel was sold by [[Canadian National Hotels]] in 1981 when that chain divested all of its properties in the early 1980s. It was purchased by Revenue Hotels and in 1989 [[Hilton International|Hilton Hotels]] took over management and the name changed to the '''Halifax Hilton'''.{{cite news|title=Nova Scotian joins Hilton hotel chain|work=Montreal Gazette|agency=Canadian Press|date=2 May 1989|page=D2}} Hilton invested $15 million to upgrade the hotel. Revenue Hotels sought to turn the hotel into a casino, but the bid failed.{{cite news|last1=Demont|first1=John|title=Westin Nova Scotian: Halifax grande dame turns 85|url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/business/1295654-westin-nova-scotian-halifax-grande-dame-turns-85|work=Halifax Chronicle-Herald|date=26 June 2015}} They closed the hotel in 1993, and the building was used as a temporary dormitory by [[Saint Mary's University (Halifax)|Saint Mary's University]] for several years after a student residence underwent emergency repairs due to an unstable wall.{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Kevin|title=Decay of university buildings in the Maritimes has reached a crisis|work=The Globe and Mail|date=5 February 1994|page=A1}} A company was hired to demolish the hotel. It was saved when the property was purchased, in April 1996, by New Castle Hotels and Resorts of Connecticut. The hotel was reportedly only a week away from demolition. An additional $4 million was put into renovating the hotel and it reopened on 1 December 1996 as '''The Westin Nova Scotian'''.{{cite news|title=A hotel by any other name|work=Halifax-HRM West Community Herald|date=3 January 2011|page=2}}{{cite web|title=The Westin Nova Scotian Hotel History|url=http://www.thewestinnovascotian.com/hotel-history|publisher=Westin Nova Scotian|accessdate=28 June 2015}} == Description == [[File:Nova Scotian Hotel and Halifax railway station 1931.jpg|thumb|left|''[[RMS Olympic]]'' docked behind the Nova Scotian in 1931.]] The hotel today is a historic 15-storey structure overlooking Cornwallis Park to the west and the seaport to the east. Cruise ships still regularly dock alongside the hotel and the adjacent railway station still offers regular service to [[Montreal]] via the ''[[Ocean (train)|Ocean]]''. There are now 310 rooms in the hotel, including 10 suites. The Crown Suite, on the 11th floor, offers sweeping views of [[Halifax Harbour]] and is where Queen Elizabeth II stayed in the past. The hotel is home to {{convert|23000|sqft|sqm}} of space for meetings, conferences, and weddings. A restaurant, Elements on Hollis, opened in 2011 and showcases Nova Scotian cuisine. Roy's Lounge is a contemporary cocktail lounge named after bartender Roy Clorey, who began bartending at the Hotel Nova Scotian in 1963. The hotel also houses a fitness centre, an indoor saltwater pool, and a business centre. The area surrounding the hotel has become thoroughly modernized in recent decades. The old coal-fired power station across the street was recently renovated to serve as the corporate headquarters of [[Nova Scotia Power]], and is the first [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED platinum]]-certified building in Atlantic Canada. The seaport district is now home to the [[Halifax Farmers' Market]], the [[Canadian Museum of Immigration at Pier 21|Canadian Museum of Immigration]], and [[NSCAD University]] – in addition to the cruise ship terminal. ==See also== {{Portal|Architecture|Canada}} * [[Architecture of Canada]] * [[List of hotels: Countries C#Canada|List of hotels in Canada]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Westin Nova Scotian}} * {{official website|thewestinnovascotian.com}} {{Canada's railway hotels}} {{Coord|display=title|name=Hotel Nova Scotian|44|38|24.5|N|63|34|6.5|W|type:landmark_region:CA-NS}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Westin Nova Scotian, The}} [[Category:2nd-millennium establishments in Nova Scotia]] [[Category:1930 establishments in Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Halifax, Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Canadian National Railway hotels]] [[Category:Hotel buildings completed in 1930]] [[Category:Hotels established in 1930]] [[Category:Hotels in Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Saint Mary's University (Halifax)]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Halifax County, Nova Scotia]] [[Category:University residences in Canada]] [[Category:Westin hotels]]

page.title: Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/First Minority Protestant Supreme Court

revision.text: :''The following discussion is an archived debate of the proposed deletion of the article below. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page. '' The result of the debate was '''delete'''. [[User:Kirill Lokshin|Kirill Lokshin]] 01:33, 6 November 2005 (UTC) ===[[First Minority Protestant Supreme Court]]=== Nominated for speedy deletion, but not a speedy candidate, so sending to AfD. I suggest merging this and [[First Majority Catholic Supreme Court]] into a single article on [[Composition of the United States Supreme Court by religion]], which would surely be of interest to some. [[User:BD2412/deletion debates|BD2412]] [[User talk:BD2412/deletion debates|'''T''']] 18:11, 31 October 2005 (UTC) :*Vote changed to '''delete'''. In retrospect, [[User:Postdlf|Postdlf]] is correct - the [[Demographics of the Supreme Court of the United States]] now covers this topic better, and the redirect, although harmless, would be useless. [[User:BD2412/deletion debates|BD2412]] [[User talk:BD2412/deletion debates|'''T''']] 22:48, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete''' POV fork and point scoring. Our [[Samuel Alito]] article has more of this bigoted nonsense too - this article is basically complaining that there are too many Jews and Catholics on the Supreme Court. [[User:Capitalistroadster|Capitalistroadster]] 18:45, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete''', as unencyclopedic. This is nothing but a potential statistic, and one about which nothing of value can be independently said. [[User:Postdlf|Postdlf]] 18:49, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete'''. What more can be said beyond this one factoid? [[User:Szyslak|{{IPA|sɪzlæk}}]] [ [[User talk:Szyslak|+t]], [[Special:Contributions/Szyslak|+c]], [[Special:Emailuser/Szyslak|+m]], [[Wikipedia:Esperanza|+e]] ] 19:09, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *Ok, I've started [[Demographics of the Supreme Court of the United States]], which I think encompasses this information in a truly encyclopedic presentation. This can redirect there. [[User:BD2412/deletion debates|BD2412]] [[User talk:BD2412/deletion debates|'''T''']] 19:34, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete''' - [[User:Dalbury|Dalbury]] 19:35, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Merge''' with [[demographics of the Supreme Court of the United States]]. [[User:Jengod|jengod]] 21:00, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Comment'''—Regarding "merging," I like the new SCOTUS demographics article, but I don't think this should exist as a redirect even if the "fact" contained in this stub gets appropriately mentioned there. Deletion is still the proper vote here, and will have no consequence on any independent editorial decisions regarding [[demographics of the Supreme Court of the United States]]. [[User:Postdlf|Postdlf]] 22:24, 31 October 2005 (UTC) **'''Comment'''. Agree. - [[User:Dalbury|Dalbury]] 22:37, 31 October 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete''' per above. [[User:Jkelly|Jkelly]] 01:02, 1 November 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete''' as per above. --[[User:Benna|Benna]] 02:28, 1 November 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete''' - [[User:Andyqaz|Andyqaz]] 03:53, 1 November 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete'''. Put the factoid in the demographics article but it's not so terribly significant as all that. [[User:Dbiv|David]] | [[User talk:Dbiv|Talk]] 10:01, 1 November 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete''' as per nominator. --[[User:RussBlau|Russ Blau]] [[User_talk:RussBlau|(talk)]] 22:33, 1 November 2005 (UTC) *'''Delete''' as the naming of this article borders on OR. Who would type that in? [[User:Jacqui M Schedler|Jacqui]] [[User_talk:Jacqui M Schedler|★]] 00:50, 2 November 2005 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.

{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Ben Willbond | image = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Benjamin Thomas Willbond | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1973|01|18}}<ref name="birth">{England and Wales Birth Index 1916–2005}</ref> | birth_place = | medium = Television, Radio, Film | nationality = English | active = 1995 – present | genre = Satire | subject = | influences = | influenced = | spouse = Charlotte Willbond | domesticpartner = | children = 2 | notable_work = ''[[Horrible Histories|Horrible Histories (2009)]]'', ''[[The Thick of It]]'', ''[[Rev. (TV series)|Rev.]]'', [[Ghosts (2019 TV series)]] | website = {{url|benwillbond.com/}} }}'''Benjamin Thomas Willbond''' (born 18 January 1973)<ref name="birth" /> is an English actor and screenwriter with numerous credits in television, radio and film best known as a member of the British [[Horrible Histories troupe]] in which he starred in the TV series ''[[Horrible Histories (2009 TV series)|Horrible Histories]]'', ''[[Yonderland]]'' and ''[[Ghosts (2019 TV series)|Ghosts]]''. He is best known for his numerous roles in the CBBC children’s program “Horrible Histories”, running from 2009 to 2013. As well as starring as various characters throughout the shows run, he also wrote many episodes, along with the other 5 main actors. He also stars as “Captain” in the 2019 TV series, “Ghosts”, with the other 5 actors he played alongside in “Horrible Histories”.
==Early life== Willbond was educated at [[Stamford School]] in Lincolnshire and read Russian and French at [[St Catherine's College, Oxford]]
==Career== Along with Arnold Widdowson, Willbond was part of the comedy duo "Ben & Arn", who won [[Perrier Award]] for "Best Newcomer" in 1999,<ref name=feca2011>{{cite web|title=Foster's Edinburgh Comedy Awards 2011|url=http://www.comedyawards.co.uk/newcomers.asp|publisher=Foster's Edinburgh Comedy Awards|accessdate=8 December 2011}}</ref> and formed the self-proclaimed "thinking man's French pop duo"<ref>{{cite web|title=Biography|url=http://www.prioriteagauche.com/Biography.htm|publisher=Priorité à Gauche|accessdate=8 December 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426040539/http://www.prioriteagauche.com/Biography.htm|archive-date=26 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Priorité à Gauche.<ref name=Guardian20050817 /> He then went on to perform his solo character shows at several [[Edinburgh Fringe Festival]]s, the last being in 2005 which also starred [[Katy Brand]] and [[Jim Field Smith]].<ref name=Guardian20050817>{{cite news|last=Daoust|first=Phil|title=Ben Willbond|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2005/aug/17/comedy.edinburghfestival20051|accessdate=8 December 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=17 August 2005}}</ref><ref>Dominic, Maxwell. "Laura Solon, Ben Willbond." ''Times, The (United Kingdom)'' 22 August 2005: Newspaper Source Plus. Web. 8 December 2011.</ref>
He is perhaps best known for his regular role in [[CBBC]]'s ''[[Horrible Histories (2009 TV series)|Horrible Histories]]'', in which he played a wide variety of historical figures, most memorably recurring roles as [[Henry VIII]] and [[Alexander the Great]]. Along with the five other members of the ''Horrible Histories'' starring cast, Willbond is also the co-creator, -writer and -star of ''[[Yonderland]]'', a family fantasy comedy series that premiered on [[SkyOne]] on 10 November 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sky1.sky.com/yonderland/sky-1-to-visit-yonderland|title=Sky1 to visit Yonderland|date=13 May 2013|work=Sky1 website|accessdate=26 July 2013}}</ref> In addition he is the co-writer of ''[[Bill (2015 film)|Bill]]'', a BBC-produced comedy film based loosely around the early life of William Shakespeare, which involved the same starring troupe.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2013/bbc-films-bill-press-release.html|title=Stars of Horrible Histories to make Shakespeare film|date=22 March 2013|work=BBC Media Centre|accessdate=26 July 2013}}</ref>
Previously, Willbond had starred in a short-lived sketch show for ITV2 called ''Laura, Ben & Him''<ref name=feca2011 /> with [[Marek Larwood]] and sometime writing partner [[Laura Solon]]. He also appeared in Solon's [[BBC Radio 4]] sketch show, [[Laura Solon: Talking and Not Talking]]. Other notable television work includes the recurring roles of Steve Warwick in the [[BBC]] comedy ''[[Rev. (TV series)|Rev]]'',<ref name=BBCRevS2E4>{{cite web|title=BBC Two – Rev., Series 2, Episode 4|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b017yzfd|publisher=BBC|accessdate=6 December 2011}}</ref> Adam Kenyon in [[BBC Four]]'s ''[[The Thick of It]]''<ref name=feca2011 /> and as a television director in the movie-length final episode of the [[Ricky Gervais]] comedy ''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]'' ([[BBC Two]]).<ref name=feca2011 /> He has also appeared in ''[[Katy Brand's Big Ass Show]]''<ref name=feca2011 /> for [[ITV2]] and ''[[Mayo (TV series)|Mayo]]''<ref name=AvalonCV /> for [[BBC One]].
Willbond's other radio credits include [[BBC Radio 4]] series ''[[Deep Trouble (radio comedy series)|Deep Trouble]]'', '' [[Double Science]]'' (co-written with [[Justin Edwards (actor)|Justin Edwards]]), ''Recorded for Training Purposes'' and the first series of ''[[Electric Ink]]''. He also starred in the YouTube romantic comedy "Nigel and Victoria."
His 2010 short film ''[[Tooty's Wedding]]'', which he co-wrote with Solon, won numerous international comedy awards and was screened as part of the [[2012 Sundance Film Festival]].<ref name="Huffington 20111215">{{cite web|last=Mann|first=Andrea|title=British Comedy Short 'Tooty's Wedding' Is Sundance-Bound (EXCLUSIVE CLIP)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2011/12/15/tootys-wedding-sundance_n_1150288.html|work=HuffPost|publisher=Aol (UK)|accessdate=15 December 2011|date=15 December 2011}}</ref> Other notable film work includes the movie ''[[Starter for 10 (film)|Starter for 10]]'' (UK 2006).<ref>Lawrenson, Edward. "Starter For Ten." ''Sight & Sound'' 16.11 (2006): 82. Associates Programs Source Plus. Web. 8 December 2011.</ref> In 2007 he had a short appearance in ''[[St Trinian's (film)|St Trinian's]]'',<ref name=AvalonCV /> as a nervous school inspector.
==Personal life== Willbond is a keen cricketer and plays for the Thunderers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.henryarlington.com/news/we-catch-actor-ben-willbond-star-horrible-histories-rev|title=We catch up with actor Ben Willbond, star of Horrible Histories, Rev.|work=Henry Arlington}}</ref> He has a degree in French and Russian from Oxford University and he can play the violin. He and wife Charlotte have two sons.
==Awards==

{{no footnotes|date=July 2015}} '''Robert Avery Model''' (born 1942) is the son of Faith Rockefeller Model (1909–1960) and [[Belgian]] [[Jean Model]]. He is the great-grandson of [[Standard Oil]] co-founder [[William Rockefeller]] (1841–1922). Model was born in [[Greenwich, Connecticut|Greenwich]], [[Connecticut]].
Model attended The [[Browning School]] and then graduated from [[Elon University|Elon College]] in [[Elon, North Carolina|Elon]], [[North Carolina]] in 1967. He is currently owner and President of Mooncrest Ranch in [[Cody, Wyoming|Cody]], [[Wyoming]]. Model is Vice President of both Stillrock Management and of Elmrock Capital in [[New York City]]. He has previously served as a Director on the boards of CapMAC, Overhills, Inc., and [[Piggly Wiggly]].
Model honored his mother by funding and naming the Faith Rockefeller Model Center for the Arts at Elon University in 1994; however on December 5, 2002, Elon announced that "[t]hrough a complex series of family circumstances the gift simply could not be realized," [http://org.elon.edu/pendulum/Issues/2002/120502/News/Model.html] and the center is now known simply as the Center for the Arts.
He is married and has three children. He was the father of the late [[Bobby Model]], who was an internationally known photographer for [[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]].
==External links== *[http://www.mooncrest.com/ Mooncrest Ranch] *[http://org.elon.edu/pendulum/Issues/2002/120502/News/Model.html Elon news article]
{{Rockefeller family}}

revision.text:
{{original research|date=October 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox hotel | hotel_name = Fort Garry Hotel | image = 2009-0519-FortGarryHotel.jpg | caption = Fort Garry Hotel in 2009 | location = 222 Broadway
[[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada | coordinates = | opening_date = December 1913 | diamonds = | closing_date = | developer = | architect = [[Ross and Macdonald]] | operator = | owner = | number_of_restaurants = | number_of_rooms = 246 | number_of_suites = | floor_area = | floors = 10 | parking = | website = [http://www.fortgarryhotel.com/ www.fortgarryhotel.com] {{Designation list |embed=yes |designation1=NHSC |designation1_offname=Fort Garry Hotel National Historic Site of Canada |designation1_date=1981 }} | footnotes = }} The '''Fort Garry Hotel''' is a historic [[hotel]] in [[Downtown Winnipeg|Downtown]] [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]]. It is one of [[Canada's grand railway hotels]] and was designated as a [[National Historic Sites of Canada|National Historic Site of Canada]] in 1981.{{CRHP|1190|Fort Garry Hotel|20 May 2012}} A national heritage park connected to the hotel and to the remains of Upper Fort Garry was completed in 2017-18.{{Cite web|title = Upper Fort Garry park work resuming|url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/upper-fort-garry-park-work-resuming-159161905.html|website = [[Winnipeg Free Press]]|accessdate = 2015-10-16|last = Kives|first = Bartley|date = 2012-06-15}} ==History== Built in 1913 by the [[Grand Trunk Pacific Railway]], it is located one block from the railway's Union Station, and was the tallest structure in the city when it was completed. Like other Canadian railway hotels, it was constructed in the "[[château]] style" (also termed the "neo-château" or "[[châteauesque]]" style), which also reflects the [[François]] I style of hotel prevalent in the eastern United States at the turn-of-the-20th-century. Henry Janeway Hardenbegh initiated the architectural trend, with [[New York City]]'s [[Plaza Hotel]] (1906–07) as his most well known structure. The Fort Garry Hotel has more than a passing similarity to The Plaza, with related features that include: the classic base, shaft, and capital divisions of the skyscraper; flat facades with slightly projecting, four-bay end pavilions; an arcade of large, segmented windows below a prominent cornice; and, the composition of the steeply sloped roofs. Architects Ross and MacFarlane of [[Montreal]] modelled their original plans for the hotel after [[Ottawa]]'s [[Château Laurier]]; plans originally called for a 10-storey structure, but two floors were added during construction. [[Image:FortGarryWinnipeg.jpg|thumb|left|The Fort Garry Hotel in 1913.]] Initially, the new hotel was to be called The Selkirk,{{Citation needed|date=August 2019}} but was instead named after [[Upper Fort Garry]], which once stood at the junction of the Red and Assiniboine Rivers. The hotel was built at a strategic location on Broadway, between Fort and Garry Streets, providing a luxury hotel for railway travellers. It was the first commercial building to be erected on Broadway and the only hotel to be built there. The hotel's early prominence led it to have many famous guests, including [[Nelson Eddy]], [[Harry Belafonte]], [[Charles Laughton]], [[Laurence Olivier]], [[Liberace]], [[Arthur Fiedler]], [[Louis Armstrong]], [[Gordie Howe]], [[Lester Pearson]], as well as [[King George VI]] and [[Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother|Queen Elizabeth]], who stayed during their 1939 visit to Canada. The hotel, originally owned by the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway, and later owned by the [[Canadian National Railway]] after Grand Trunk was nationalized and absorbed into CN. In 1979, the hotel was purchased by the prominent [[John Draper Perrin]] family of Winnipeg, who operated it as an independent hotel until 1987. It was then owned for a few years by a company controlled by Quebec hotelier Raymond Malenfant. Presently it is run as an independent hotel. According to local folklore, the hotel is haunted.{{cite web|title=Canada's top five haunted travel hot spots|url=http://www.canada.com/Canada+five+haunted+travel+spots/5603662/story.html|publisher=Canada.com|accessdate=14 November 2012|date=26 October 2011}} The Fort Garry Hotel is infamous for its haunted Room 202. A woman apparently committed suicide in the room many years ago after hearing of the death of her husband in a car accident. Overcome with grief, she hanged herself in the closet.{{Cite web|title = Fort Garry Hotel, Winnipeg, Canada|url = http://www.hauntedrooms.com/fort-garry-hotel-winnipeg-canada|website = HauntedRooms.com|accessdate = 2015-10-16}} === CNR Radio === The Fort Garry Hotel was the site of the Winnipeg studio of [[CNR Radio]], the precursor to CBC Radio, between 1923 and 1932, using the original CKY transmitter on 665 KHz, moving to 780 KHz in 1925. CNR purchased time on stations they did not own, called "phantom" stations.{{Cite web|url=http://www.broadcasting-history.ca/listing_and_histories/television/cbw-am|title=History of Canadian Broadcasting: CBW (AM)|last=|first=|date=|website=Canadian Communications Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 28, 2019}} == Notable events ==
== See also == * [[Ida Albo]], managing partner ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.fortgarryhotel.com Official Site] * [http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=112714 Emporis Listing] {{Canada's railway hotels}} {{NHSC}} {{coord|49|53|16|N|97|08|12|W|type:landmark_region:CA-MB|display=title}} [[Category:Canadian National Railway hotels]] [[Category:Grand Trunk Pacific Railway hotels]] [[Category:Hotels in Manitoba]] [[Category:Hotels established in 1913]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Winnipeg]] [[Category:Châteauesque architecture in Canada]] [[Category:National Historic Sites in Manitoba]] [[Category:Ross and Macdonald buildings]] [[Category:Hotels on the National Historic Sites of Canada register]] [[Category:Reportedly haunted locations in Winnipeg]] [[Category:1913 establishments in Manitoba]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Hyperdrive (disambiguation)]] (link changed to [[Hyperdrive (British TV series)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{refimprove|date=December 2011}} The '''Dutch Elm Conservatoire''' is a British [[sketch comedy]] group, made up of five writers and actors: [[Stephen Evans (actor)|Stephen Evans]], [[Jim Field Smith]], [[Rufus Jones (comedian)|Rufus Jones]], [[Renton Skinner|Dan Renton Skinner]] and Jordan Long. They performed on the comedy circuit in London, Edinburgh and on tour. In 2005 they were nominated for the prestigious [[Perrier Award]] at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]]. The [[wiktionary:troupe|troupe]] first met together as a five towards the end 2002, with their stage debut in February 2003.
Subsequent to this, the [[BBC]] [[Contract|commissioned]] them to record a [[BBC Radio 4]] pilot. The resulting script, CONSPIRACY, was then developed for the stage. They took this new live show back to the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] in August 2005, again at the Pleasance Courtyard playing to sell-out audiences and picking up a [[Perrier Award]] nomination and a rare 5-star review from the Scotsman, amongst others. The show was directed by Ed Curtis. On returning to London they performed the show to a sell-out West End audience, and early in 2006 they embarked on their first UK Tour which finished in March 2006. As a group, the Dutch Elm Conservatoire have appeared on various TV and radio [[Radio programming|programmes]], including ''Loose Ends'', ''The Milk Run'' and ''28 Acts in 28 Minutes'' (all for the BBC). However, the four of them are busy actors and writers in their own right, with an extensive range of credits for screen, stage and radio. Between them, they have infiltrated almost every new comedy series of recent years on British television, including [[Hyperdrive (British TV series)|Hyperdrive]] (BBC), [[Nighty Night]] (BBC), ''Snuff Box'' (BBC), ''Mike Bassett: Manager'' ([[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]), ''Secret Smile'' ([[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]), [[The Office (UK TV series)|The Office]] (BBC), ''My Life in Film''(BBC), ''The Robinsons'' (BBC), ''According to Bex'' (BBC), ''The Only Boy for Me'' ([[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]), ''[[Peep Show (TV series)|Peep Show]]'' ([[Channel 4]]), [[My Family]] (BBC), [[Coupling (UK TV series)|Coupling]] (BBC), [[Extras (TV series)|Extras]] (BBC), [[Love Soup]] (BBC), ''Fear of Fanny'' (BBC), ''15 Storeys High'' (BBC) and ''[[Bedsitcom]]'' ([[Channel 4]]), not to mention films and radio. They also crop up frequently in [[voice-overs]], [[commercials]] and [[corporation|corporate]] work in [[UK|Britain]] and abroad, and have writing credits across all the major [[terrestrial television|terrestrial]] and [[Digital data|digital]] channels.
They last performed as a five at the August 2006 [[Edinburgh Fringe]] and the [[Belfast]] theatre festival (Nov '06), with a show entitled ''Dutch Elm Conservatoire in Prison''
During 2007/08 ''The Dutch Elm Conservatoire'' could be seen performing on the [[BBC Three]] comedy show entitled ''Comedy Shuffle'' and heard on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s series of ''28 Acts in 28 Minutes''. They also made several appearances in the second series of ''Comedy Cuts'' for [[ITV2]] during 2008.
== External links == *[http://unitedagents.co.uk/ Talent agent United Agents] *[http://www.amandahowardassociates.co.uk/ Talent agent AHA] *[http://www.independenttalent.com/ Independent Talent Group Ltd]
[[Category:British comedy writers]] [[Category:Comedy collectives]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox river | name = Lagoa do Fogo | name_native = Lagoa do Fogo | name_native_lang = | name_other = Lake/Lagoon of Fire | name_etymology = | nickname =Fogo <!---------------------- IMAGE & MAP --> | image = Lagoa do Fogo on Sao Miguel in the Azores of Portugal on the planet Earth.jpg | image_size = 235px | image_caption = A view of Lagoa do Fogo from the scenic overlook of Lagoa do Fogo III | map = | map_size = 235 | map_caption = Location of the waterbody on the island of São Miguel, in the archipelago of the [[Azores]] | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_size = 235 | pushpin_map_caption= <!---------------------- LOCATION --> | subdivision_type1 = Country | subdivision_name1 = [[Portugal]] | subdivision_type2 = Autonomous Region | subdivision_name2 = [[Azores]] | subdivision_type3 = Group | subdivision_name3 = [[Azores#Physical geography|Eastern]] | subdivision_type4 = Island | subdivision_name4 = [[São Miguel Island|São Miguel]] | subdivision_type5 = Municipalities | subdivision_name5 = [[Ribeira Grande, Azores|Ribeira Grande]], [[Vila Franca do Campo]], [[Lagoa, Azores|Lagoa]] <!---------------------- PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS --> | length = {{convert|3|km|mi|abbr=on}} | width_min = | width_avg = | width_max = | depth_min = | depth_avg = | depth_max = | discharge1_location= [[Atlantic Ocean]] | discharge1_min = | discharge1_avg = | discharge1_max = <!---------------------- BASIN FEATURES --> | source1 = [[Água de Pau Massif]] | source1_location = | source1_coordinates= | source1_elevation = | mouth = | mouth_location = | mouth_coordinates = | mouth_elevation = | progression = | river_system = | basin_size = {{convert|21.82|km2|abbr=on}} | tributaries_left = | tributaries_right = | custom_label = | custom_data = | extra = }} '''Lagoa do Fogo''' (''Lake/Lagoon of Fire'') is a [[crater lake]] within the [[Água de Pau Massif]] [[stratovolcano]] in the center of the island of [[São Miguel Island|São Miguel]] in the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] archipelago of the [[Azores]]. The highest lake located on the island of São Miguel, the region is protected by governmental regulation that does not permit the construction around the lake.
==History== Since 1974, the ''Lagoa do Fogo'' had been under the administration of national legislation as a protected area, forming the ''Reserva da Lagoa do Fogo'' (''Natural Reserve of Lagoa do Fogo'') an area that includes approximately {{convert|2182|ha|m2}}, founded by Decree-law 152/74 (15 April 1974). It was also covered under a supplementary Decree-Law 9/79.<ref>IGP (2005); DCA/UA (2004); DRA (2004); DROTRH/SRA et al. (2001)</ref>
The ''Reserva Natural da Lagoa do Fogo'' was created in 1982, under terms of Regional Decree 10/82/A on 18 June 1982.<ref name="Santos1991">Santos et al. (1991a)</ref><ref name="AIdeias">Ana Ideias (May 2012)</ref><ref name="AmbienteRN">{{citation |title=Reserva Natural da Lagoa do Fogo |editor=DRA |publisher=Direção Regional do Ambiente |language=Portuguese |year=2015 |location=Horta (Azores), Portugal}}</ref> Part of the area was included in the Natura 2000 network, and classified as the ''Site of Communitarian Importance of Lagoa do Fogo''.<ref name=AmbienteRN/>
The nature reserve was integrated into the Nature Park of São Miguel, under Decree-Law 19/2008A (8 July 2008), which included the entire watershed of the Laoga.<ref name="DR4261">Diário da República, (8 July 2008), p.4261</ref>
==Geography== [[File:Lagoa do Fogo, Miradouro da Serra da Barrosa, Vila Franca do Campo, ilha de São Miguel, Açores.JPG|thumb|235px|left|A view of the lake from the scenic overlook of Pico do Barrosa]] [[File:2012-10-15 13-46-19 Portugal Azores Lombadas.JPG|thumb|235px|left|The fine, sedimentary beach of Lagoa do Fogo, with view of crater rim]] Lagoa do Fogo is one of the largest of the waterbodies in the Azores, and occupies the central caldera of the [[Água de Pau Massif]], in the central area of the island of São Miguel.<ref name=AmbienteRN/> The caldera is the youngest volcano on the island of São Miguel, formed approximately 15 000 years ago, resulting from the collapse at the top of the volcano, some 5000 years ago. The last eruption occurred in 1563.<ref name=AmbienteRN/> It falls within the borders of the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parishes]] of [[Conceição (Ribeira Grande)|Conceição]], [[Matriz (Ribeira Grande)|Matriz]] and [[Água de Alto]], in the [[Concelho|municipalities]] of [[Ribeira Grande (Azores)|Ribeira Grande]] and [[Vila Franca do Campo]], respectively.<ref name=AIdeias/><ref>Pacheco et al. (2010)</ref>
It is part of the hydrological watershed of the same name. The margins of the lake are located {{convert|575|m|ft}} above sea level, although the crater rim, which extends to Pico da Barrosa is located at approximately {{convert|949|m|ft}} altitude.<ref name=Santos1991/><ref name=AIdeias/><ref name=AmbienteRN/> The internal flanks of the crater (characterized by abrupt 48º cliffs) are occupied by the elliptical lake, {{convert|3|x|2.5|km|mi}} and {{convert|30|m|ft}} deep.<ref name=AIdeias/><ref name=AmbienteRN/><ref name="DROTRH">DROTRH/SRA et al. (2001)</ref>
The carved relief affects the course of hydrographic run-off, which is accentuated by torrential precipitation in the region, resulting in accentuated erosion and deposition along the margins.<ref name=AIdeias/><ref>LNEC (1991)</ref> A majority of the watercourses are temporary or torrential, with the greatest run-off occurring in the winter, and little in the summer, with few permanent ravines.<ref name=AIdeias/><ref name=DROTRH/> There are only two permanent effluents in the lake, one to the western crater rim in Barrosa, and the other in the south-southeast.<ref name=Santos1991/><ref name=AIdeias/> The lake is maintained from mainly, direct precipitation over the caldera and from superficial run-off from the watersheds, where nutrient infiltration is common. The lake's waters support local aquifers in the lowlands and provide potable water to the settlements in the southern flanks of the caldera.<ref name=Santos1991/><ref name=AIdeias/>
===Biome=== From the west to south, the crater is covered in brush and scrub, while in the east and north (where declives are minor) the vegetation is much denser and covered in some forest. Between the crater wall and lake is a northern margin/beach consisting of sedimentary, with little vegetation.<ref name=Santos1991/><ref name=AIdeias/> Much of the land surrounding the crater is occupied by largely parcels of median {{convert|283|ha|m2}} in size, {{convert|61|ha|m2}} of forested production and endemic Macronesian species.<ref name=AIdeias/> Since 2001, the caldera and lake have been part of the Rede Natura network of sites of communitarian interest, for special conservation by European Commission (dated 28 December 2001) and the Habitats Directive 92/43/CEE.<ref>DRA (2004); DROTRH/SRA et al. (2001)</ref> There are no human settlements or operations within the crater.<ref name=AIdeias/>
Within the perimeter of the nature reserve, lake and caldera flanks, are many endemic Azorean plant species, including the Azores juniper (''[[Juniperus brevifolia]]''), Azores laurel (''[[Laurus azorica]]'') and buckthorn (''[[Frangula azorica]]''), in addition to St. John's wort (''[[Hypericum foliosum]]''), Azores heather (''[[Erica azorica]]'') and Mediterranean spurge (''[[Euphorbia stygiana]]'').<ref name=AmbienteRN/>
Small birds are the primary animal species within the caldera, in addition to some larger birds, such as kites or seagulls; terrestrial birds include the Azores wood pigeon (''[[Azores wood pigeon|Columba palumbus azorica]]''), Azorean buzzard (''[[common buzzard#Systematics|Buteo buteo rothschildi]]''), the grey wagtail (''[[grey wagtail|Motocilla cinerea]]'') and the Azorean common blackbird ''([[common blackbird#Subspecies|Turdus merula azorensis]]''), as well as marine birds such as yellow-legged gull (''[[Larus cachinnans atlantis]]'') and the common tern (''[[Sterna hirundo]]'').<ref name=AmbienteRN/>
==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Sources=== * {{citation |last=Scarth |first=Alwyn |author2=Tanguy |first2=Jean-Claude |title=Volcanoes of Europe |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2001 |isbn=0-19-521754-3}} * [http://www.volcano.si.edu/world/volcano.cfm?vnum=1802-09= Global Volcanism Program: Agua de Pau] * {{citation |last=Santos |first=M.C.R. |last2=Santana |first2=F.J.P. |last3=Rodrigues |first3=A.M.F. |last4=Sobral |first4=P. |year=1991 |title=O Controlo da Eutrofização nas Lagoas de S. Miguel – Açores. Parte I – A Lagoa das Sete Cidades. Relatório Técnico. |publisher=Departamento de Ciências e Engenharia do Ambiente, Faculdade de Ciências e Tecnologia, Universidade Nova de Lisboa |location=Lisbon, Portugal |language=Portuguese |pages=136}} * {{citation |last=Santos |first=M.C.R. |last2=Santana |first2=F.J.P. |last3=Rodrigues |first3=A.M.F. |last4=Sobral |first4=P. |year=1991 |title=O Controlo da Eutrofização nas Lagoas de S. Miguel – Açores. Parte III – A Lagoa do Fogo. Relatório Técnico. |publisher=Departamento de Ciências e Engenharia do Ambiente, Faculdade de Ciências e Tecnologia, Universidade Nova de Lisboa |location=Lisbon, Portugal |language=Portuguese |pages=59}} * {{citation |editor=DROTRH/SRA & Instituto da Água/MAOT |year=2001 |title=Plano Regional da Água – Relatório Técnico. |publisher=Direcção Regional do Ordenamento do Território e dos Recursos Hídricos/Secretaria Regional do Ambiente, Instituto da Água/Ministério do Ambiente e do Ordenamento do Território |location=Horta (Azores), Portugal |language=Portuguese |pages=414}} * {{citation |first=Ana Sofia Nunes |last=Ideias |url=http://run.unl.pt/bitstream/10362/8191/1/Ideias_2012.pdf |title=Caracterização Trófica e Modelação da Lagoa do Fogo (S. Miguel, Açores): Dissertação para a obtenção do Grau de Mestre em Engenharia do Ambiente |language=Portuguese |publisher=Faculdade de Ciências e Tecnologia, Universidade Nova de Lisboa |location=Lisbon, Portugal |date=May 2012}} * {{citation |url=http://www.azores.gov.pt/NR/rdonlyres/55615D95-04AE-47E6-BFDB-199C5332F7C3/530137/DLR_19_2008_A.pdf |title=Decreto Legislativo Regional 19/2008/A: Parque Natural da Ilha de São Miguel |accessdate=24 October 2016 |language=Portuguese |pages=4242–4246 |publisher=Diário da República |edition=Série 1 |issue=130 |date=8 July 2008 |location=Lisbon, Portugal}}

revision.text:
{{For|the Belgian television drama series|Hotel Beau Séjour}} {{Infobox building |name = Delta Hotels Beausejour |status = |image = Downtownmoncton.JPG |image_size = 250px |caption = |location = 750 Main Street
[[Moncton]], [[New Brunswick]]
E1C 1E6 |coordinates = {{coord|46.0886|N|64.7765|W|type:landmark_region:CA-NB|display=inline,title}} |start_date = |completion_date = 1972 |architect = |owner =InnVest Hotels |cost = |floor_area = |top_floor = |floor_count = 10 |building_type = Hotel |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|35.0|m|ft|abbr=on}} |elevator_count =2 |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |opening = |developer = }} The 310-room '''Delta Hotels Beausejour''' was opened in 1972 by the [[Canadian National Railway]] in the railway hub of [[Moncton]], [[New Brunswick]]. The first class hotel was operated by [[Canadian National Hotels]] until that chain was purchased by [[Canadian Pacific Hotels]] in 1988. CP Hotels placed the Beauséjour under its [[Delta Hotels]] subsidiary in 1999 when CP Hotels took over the [[Fairmont Hotels and Resorts]] chain, assuming the latter's name. The hotel operates under the Delta banner as the '''Delta Hotels Beausejour''' and has the most rooms of any hotel in the province. The hotel building was purchased by [[Legacy Hotels Real Estate Investment Trust|Legacy Hotels]] in 2006 and underwent a major renovation, which finished in 2008. ==See also== * [[List of tallest buildings in Moncton]] ==References== * [http://www.deltahotels.com/hotels/hotels.php?hotelId=27 Info on hotel from Deltahotels.com] {{Moncton landmarks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beausejour}} [[Category:Canadian National Railway hotels]] [[Category:Hotels in New Brunswick]] [[Category:Canadian Pacific Railway hotels]] [[Category:Fairmont Hotels and Resorts]] [[Category:Hotels established in 1972]] [[Category:Canadian building and structure stubs|Hotel Beausejour]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Moncton|Hotel Beausejour]] {{Canada-hotel-struct-stub}} {{NewBrunswick-struct-stub}}

:''The following discussion is an archived debate of the proposed deletion of the article below. '''Please do not modify it.''' '' The result of the debate was SPEEDILY DELETED -- [[User:Francs2000|Francs]][http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk:Francs2000&action=edit§ion=new 2000] [[Image:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|25px|]] 18:30, 31 October 2005 (UTC) ===[[Steve Horn]]=== Attack page, possibly also patent nonsense. Already put it up for speedy, but I don't like to have A6 pages up any longer than necessary. '''Delete'''. -[[User:Colin Kimbrell|Colin Kimbrell]] 18:24, 31 October 2005 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's talk page or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.

{{Infobox TV channel |name = Kanal 5 | logofile = Kanal 5 logo Danmark.png | logosize = 200px | share = 2.9% | share as of = 2008 | share source = TNS-Gallup |country = [[United Kingdom]] |broadcast area = [[Denmark]] |owner = [[SBS Discovery Media]]
([[Discovery Communications]]) |launch = 1 January 2000 (as TV Danmark 1)
4 April 2004 (as Kanal 5) |replaced names = TV Danmark 1 |web = [http://www.kanal5.dk www.kanal5.dk] | terr serv 1 = [[Boxer TV A/S|Boxer]] | terr chan 1 = Channel 5 | sat serv 1 = [[Canal Digital]] | sat chan 1 = Channel 5 | cable serv 1 = [[YouSee]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 5 | cable serv 2 = | cable chan 2 = }} '''Kanal 5''' (''Channel 5'') is a [[Denmark|Danish]] subscription [[television channel]] operated by [[SBS Discovery Media]], a subsidiary of [[Discovery Communications]]. The station is broadcast to Denmark by satellite from [[London]], showing mainly films, [[United States|US]] drama shows and sports. Kanal 5 aired the Danish version of [[So You Think You Can Dance (US)|So You Think You Can Dance]]. Kanal 5 owns the Danish broadcast rights to show [[Spain|Spanish]] [[football (soccer)|football]] from [[La Primera Division]], and along with [[Canal Digital]] it shares the rights to show English [[Premier League]] football. {{As of|2007}} Kanal 5 has bought the rights to show the [[James Bond]] movies. Kanal 5 is distributed through [[cable television|cable]] and [[satellite television|satellite]]. == Programming== * [[Lost (TV series)|Lost]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.kanal5.dk/ Official Kanal 5 site] {{Danish television channels}} [[Category:Television stations in Denmark]] [[Category:Discovery Networks]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2000]] [[Category:Television channel articles with incorrect naming style]] {{Denmark-tv-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox book| | name = Wall Around a Star | title_orig = | translator = | cover_artist = [[David B. Mattingly]] | image = WallAroundAStar.jpg | caption = First edition | author = [[Frederik Pohl]]
[[Jack Williamson]] | country = United States | language = English | series = [[Saga of Cuckoo]] | genre = [[Science fiction]] | publisher = [[Del Rey Books]] | release_date = January 12, 1983 | isbn = 0-345-28995-1 | oclc = 9184254{{cite web|title=Wall Around a Star|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/wall-around-a-star/oclc/9184254&referer=brief_results|work=OCLC Worldcat|accessdate=1 April 2014}} | pages = 275 | awards =1984 [[Locus Award]] - [[Locus Award for Best Science Fiction Novel|Best SF Novel]] (21st place) | preceded_by =[[Farthest Star]] }} '''''Wall Around a Star''''' is a [[science fiction]] novel by American writers [[Frederik Pohl]] and [[Jack Williamson]], the second book of the ''[[Saga of Cuckoo]]'' series, following ''[[Farthest Star]]''. The book was published by [[Del Rey Books]] on January 12, 1983, with cover art by [[David Burroughs Mattingly|David Mattingly]].{{cite web | url = http://www.iblist.com/book19581.htm | title = Book Information: Wall Around a Star | publisher = Internet Book List | accessdate = 2013-05-14}} In this novel linguist Jen Babylon is called on to translate alien records which may explain the nature of "Cuckoo", a sphere built around a star, and thus save the galaxy.{{cite journal|last=Nickerson|first=Susan L|title=Wall Around a Star (book)|journal=Library Journal|date=1983-02-15|volume=108|issue=4|page=415}} == References == {{reflist}} {{Frederik Pohl}} [[Category:1983 American novels]] [[Category:1983 science fiction novels]] [[Category:Literary collaborations]] [[Category:Novels by Frederik Pohl]] [[Category:Novels by Jack Williamson]] [[Category:Del Rey books]] [[Category:Books with cover art by David Burroughs Mattingly]] {{1980s-sf-novel-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Iihsa logo.png|thumb|200px|right|The IIHSA logo combines images from Classical Greece and prehistoric Ireland]] The '''Irish Institute of Hellenic Studies at Athens''' (IIHSA) ({{lang-ga|Institiúid Éireannach san Ataen don Léann Heilléanach}}; {{lang-el|Ιρλανδικό Ινστιτούτο Ελληνικών Σπουδών στην Αθήνα}}) is one of the 17 [[List of Foreign Archaeological Institutes in Greece|foreign archaeological institutes]] operating in [[Athens]], [[Greece]].
==General information, mission== The IIHSA was officially founded in 1995 and has been fully operational since 2002. It aims to promote, coordinate, and assist Irish or Irish-based researchers who are active in Greece, to develop Irish-based archaeological projects in Greece, to raise the awareness and profile of [[Hellenic studies|Hellenic Studies]] in [[Ireland]] and to promote Irish culture in Greece.
[[Image:Iihsa premises.jpg|thumb|200px|right|The IIHSA premises, in an [[Art Déco]] building in [[Exarcheia]].]]
==Activities== Apart from its archaeological fieldwork (below), the IIHSA runs a lecture series, hosts occasional seminars and exhibitions, organises annual archaeological study tours for Irish students and operates a programme of bursaries enabling Irish students to undertake research in Greece. It also provides accommodation for Irish and international scholars active in Athens. Since 2007, the IIHSA organises annual conferences on changing (normally archaeological) topics. It has also been involved in Irish-themed cultural events outside Athens.
==Archaeological projects== Since 2003, the IIHSA has been conducting an [[archaeological field survey|archeological survey]] at [[Leivathos]] ([[Kefalonia]]); in 2007, it began an [[Excavation (archaeology)|excavation]] at [[Priniatikos Pyrgos]] (East [[Crete]]).
==Bibliography== *E. Korka et al. (eds.): Foreign Archaeological Schools in Greece, 160 Years, Athens, Hellenic Ministry of Culture, 2006, p. 102-107.
==External links== * [http://www.iihsa.ie/welcome.html IIHSA website]
{{coord|37|59|26|N|23|44|06|E|source:dewiki|display=title}}
[[Category:Charities based in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Foreign Archaeological Institutes in Greece]]

revision.text:
{{infobox embryology |Name= Fetal circulation |Image=2916_Fetal_Circulatory_System-02.jpg |Caption=The fetal circulatory system includes three shunts to divert blood from undeveloped and partially functioning organs, as well as blood supply to and from the placenta. |Width=300 | GivesRiseTo = [[Circulatory system]] |Latin= }} {{Organ system development}} In [[animal]]s that [[viviparity|give live birth]], the '''fetal circulation''' is the [[circulatory system]] of a [[fetus]]. The term usually encompasses the entire [[placenta#fetoplacental circulation|fetoplacental circulation]], which includes the [[umbilical cord]] and the [[blood vessel]]s within the [[placenta]] that carry [[fetal hemoglobin|fetal blood]]. The fetal (prenatal) circulation differs from normal postnatal circulation,mainly because the lungs are not in use. Instead, the [[fetus]] obtains [[oxygen]] and [[nutrient]]s from the mother through the [[placenta]] and the [[umbilical cord]].{{cite book |last=Whitaker |first=Kent |chapter=Fetal Circulation |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=R3WK8XyAHYgC&pg=PA18 |title=Comprehensive Perinatal and Pediatric Respiratory Care |publisher=Delmar Thomson Learning |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-7668-1373-1 |pages=18–20}} The advent of [[breathing]] and the severance of the [[umbilical cord]] prompt various [[neuroendocrine]] changes that shortly transform fetal circulation into postnatal circulation. The fetal circulation of humans has been extensively studied by the [[health science]]s. Much is known also of fetal circulation in other animals, especially [[livestock]] and [[model organism]]s such as mice, through the health sciences, [[veterinary science]], and [[life science]]s generally. ==Structure== Blood from the [[placenta]] is carried to the [[fetus]] by the [[umbilical vein]]. In humans, less than a third of this enters the fetal ''[[ductus venosus]]'' and is carried to the [[inferior vena cava]],{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0002-9378(00)70504-7 | last1 = Kiserud | first1 = T. | last2 = Rasmussen | first2 = S. | last3 = Skulstad | first3 = S. | title = Blood flow and the degree of shunting through the ductus venosus in the human fetus | journal = American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology | volume = 182 | issue = 1 Pt 1 | pages = 147–153 | year = 2000 | pmid = 10649170}} while the rest enters the [[liver]] proper from the inferior border of the liver. The branch of the [[umbilical vein]] that supplies the right [[Liver#Lobes|lobe]] of the [[liver]] first joins with the [[portal vein]]. The blood then moves to the [[right atrium]] of the [[heart]]. In the fetus, there is an opening between the [[right atrium|right]] and [[left atrium]] (the ''[[foramen ovale (heart)|foramen ovale]]''), and most of the blood flows through this hole directly into the left atrium from the right atrium, thus bypassing [[pulmonary circulation]]. The continuation of this blood flow is into the left ventricle, and from there it is [[pump]]ed through the [[aorta]] into the body. Some of the blood moves from the aorta through the [[internal iliac arteries]] to the [[umbilical arteries]], and re-enters the [[placenta]], where [[carbon dioxide]] and other waste products from the fetus are taken up and enter the maternal circulation. Some of the [[blood]] entering the right atrium does not pass directly to the [[left atrium]] through the ''[[foramen ovale (heart)|foramen ovale]]'', but enters the [[right ventricle]] and is pumped into the [[pulmonary artery]]. In the fetus, there is a special connection between the [[pulmonary artery]] and the [[aorta]], called the ''[[ductus arteriosus]]'', which directs most of this blood away from the lungs (which are not being used for [[respiration (physiology)|respiration]] at this point as the [[fetus]] is suspended in [[amniotic fluid]]). ===Placenta=== {{main|Placenta}} The circulatory system of the mother is not directly connected to that of the fetus, so the placenta functions as the respiratory center for the fetus as well as a site of filtration for plasma nutrients and wastes. Water, glucose, amino acids, vitamins, and inorganic salts freely diffuse across the placenta along with oxygen. The uterine arteries carry blood to the placenta, and the blood permeates the sponge-like material there. Oxygen then diffuses from the placenta to the chorionic villus, an [[Pulmonary alveolus|alveolus]]-like structure, where it is then carried to the umbilical vein. ===Before birth=== [[File:Fetal circulation.png|thumb|right|220px|Diagram of the human [[fetal circulatory system]].]] The [[circulatory system]], consisting of the heart and blood vessels, forms relatively early during embryonic development, and continues to develop in complexity within the growing fetus. A functional circulatory system is a biological necessity, since mammalian tissues can not grow more than a few cell layers thick without an active blood supply. The prenatal circulation of blood is different than the postnatal circulation, mainly because the lungs are not in use. The fetus obtains [[oxygen]] and nutrients from the mother through the [[placenta]] and the [[umbilical cord]]. Blood from the placenta is carried to the fetus by the [[umbilical vein]]. About half of this enters the fetal ''[[ductus venosus]]'' and is carried to the [[inferior vena cava]], while the other half enters the [[liver]] proper from the inferior border of the liver. The branch of the umbilical vein that supplies the right lobe of the liver first joins with the [[portal vein]]. The blood then moves to the right atrium of the [[heart]]. In the fetus, there is an opening between the right and left atrium (the ''[[foramen ovale (heart)|foramen ovale]]''), and most of the blood flows from the right into the left atrium, thus bypassing [[pulmonary circulation]]. The majority of blood flow is into the left ventricle from where it is pumped through the [[aorta]] into the body. Some of the blood moves from the aorta through the internal iliac arteries to the umbilical arteries, and re-enters the placenta, where [[carbon dioxide]] and other waste products from the fetus are taken up and enter the woman's circulation. Some of the blood from the right atrium does not enter the left atrium, but enters the right ventricle and is pumped into the [[pulmonary artery]]. In the fetus, there is a special connection between the pulmonary artery and the aorta, called the ''[[ductus arteriosus]]'', which directs most of this blood away from the lungs (which aren't being used for respiration at this point as the fetus is suspended in [[amniotic fluid]]). ===After birth=== {{Main|Adaptation to extrauterine life}} At birth, when the infant breathes for the first time, there is a decrease in the resistance in the pulmonary vasculature, which causes the pressure in the left atrium to increase relative to the pressure in the right atrium. This leads to the closure of the [[Foramen ovale (heart)|foramen ovale]], which is then referred to as the [[fossa ovalis (heart)|fossa ovalis]]. Additionally, the increase in the concentration of oxygen in the blood leads to a decrease in [[prostaglandins]], causing closure of the [[ductus arteriosus]]. These closures prevent blood from bypassing pulmonary circulation, and therefore allow the neonate's blood to become oxygenated in the newly operational lungs. {{Cite book | last1 = Le | first1 = Tao | first2 = Vikas | last2 = Bhushan | first3 = Neil | last3 = Vasan | title = First Aid for the USMLE Step 1: 2010 20th Anniversary Edition | location = USA | publisher = McGraw-Hill | year= 2010 | page = 123 | isbn = 978-0-07-163340-6 }} Sometimes these postnatal closures are incomplete or absent. The vessels or [[anastomosis|cross-connections]] remain open ([[wikt:patent#Adjective|patent]]), leading to the following conditions: * [[Atrial septal defect#Patent foramen ovale|Patent foramen ovale]] in the heart * [[Patent ductus arteriosus]] in the [[great vessels]] * [[Ductus venosus#Patent ductus venosus|Patent ductus venosus]] in the great vessels ===Adult remnants=== Remnants of the fetal circulation can be found in the adult.Dudek, Ronald and Fix, James. ''[https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0781757266&id=LGcI-FVCruEC&pg=RA1-PA54&lpg=RA1-PA54&ots=2h9BlGiwkB&dq=%22Remnants+of+fetal+circulatory%22&sig=FFhRCd92q-wfUbGgR81vu62sBMA#PRA1-PA54,M1 Board Review Series Embryology]'' (Lippincott 2004). Retrieved 2007-03-04.University of Michigan Medical School, [http://www.med.umich.edu/lrc/coursepages/M1/embryology/embryo/18changesatbirth.htm Fetal Circulation and Changes at Birth] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070527150844/http://www.med.umich.edu/lrc/coursepages/M1/embryology/embryo/18changesatbirth.htm |date=2007-05-27 }}. Retrieved 2007-03-04. {| class="wikitable" style="line-height:1.3em" ! Fetal ! Develops |- | ''[[Foramen ovale (heart)|foramen ovale]]'' | ''[[Fossa ovalis (heart)|fossa ovalis]]'' |- | ''[[ductus arteriosus]]'' | ''[[ligamentum arteriosum]]'' |- | extra-[[hepatic]] portion of the fetal left [[umbilical vein]] | ''[[ligamentum teres hepatis]]''
("round ligament of the liver") |- | intra-hepatic portion of the fetal left umbilical vein
(''[[ductus venosus]]'') | ''[[ligamentum venosum]]'' |- | [[Anatomical terms of location#Proximal and distal|proximal]] portions of the fetal left and right [[Umbilical artery|umbilical arteries]]  | [[umbilical branches]] of the [[internal iliac arteries]]  |- | [[Anatomical terms of location#Proximal and distal|distal]] portions of the fetal left and right umbilical arteries | [[medial umbilical ligaments]]
|} In addition to differences in circulation, the developing fetus also employs a different type of oxygen [[Transport protein|transport molecule]] in its [[hemoglobin]] from that when it is born and breathing its own oxygen. [[Fetal hemoglobin]] enhances the fetus' ability to draw oxygen from the placenta. Its [[oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve]] is shifted to the left, meaning that it is able to absorb oxygen at lower concentrations than adult hemoglobin. This enables fetal hemoglobin to absorb oxygen from adult hemoglobin in the placenta, where the oxygen pressure is lower than at the lungs. Until around six months' old, the human infant's hemoglobin molecule is made up of two [[Hemoglobin, alpha 1|alpha]] and two [[HBG1|gamma chain]]s (2α2γ). The gamma chains are gradually replaced by [[HBB|beta chain]]s until the molecule becomes [[hemoglobin A]] with its two alpha and two beta chains (2α2β). ==Physiology== The core concept behind fetal circulation is that fetal [[hemoglobin]] (HbF){{cite journal|vauthors=Edoh D, Antwi-Bosaiko C, Amuzu D |title=Fetal hemoglobin during infancy and in sickle cell adults|journal=African Health Sciences|date=March 2006|volume=6|issue=1|pages=51–54| pmc=1831961|pmid=16615829}} has a higher affinity for oxygen than does adult hemoglobin, which allows a diffusion of oxygen from the mother's circulatory system to the fetus. ===Blood pressure=== It is the fetal heart and not the mother's heart that builds up the fetal blood pressure to drive its blood through the fetal circulation. Intracardiac pressure remains identical between the right and left ventricles of the human fetus.{{cite journal|vauthors = Johnson P, Maxwell DJ, Tynan MJ, Allan LD|title=Intracardiac pressures in the human fetus|journal=Heart|year=2000|volume=84|issue=1|pages=59–63|issn=0007-0769|doi=10.1136/heart.84.1.59|pmid=10862590|url=http://heart.bmj.com/content/84/1/59.full|pmc=1729389}} The blood pressure in the fetal aorta is approximately 30 mmHg at 20 weeks of gestation, and increases to ca 45 mmHg at 40 weeks of gestation.{{cite journal |pages=673–81 |doi=10.1002/uog.6137 |title=Blood pressure estimation in the human fetal descending aorta |year=2008 |last1=Struijk |first1=P. C. |last2=Mathews |first2=V. J. |last3=Loupas |first3=T. |last4=Stewart |first4=P. A. |last5=Clark |first5=E. B. |last6=Steegers |first6=E. A. P. |last7=Wladimiroff |first7=J. W. |journal=Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynecology |volume=32 |issue=5 |pmid=18816497}} The fetal [[pulse pressure]] is ca 20 mmHg at 20 weeks of gestation, increasing to ca 30 mmHg at 40 weeks of gestation. The blood pressure decreases when passing through the placenta. In the [[arteria umbilicalis]], it is ca 50 mmHg. It falls to 30 mmHg in the capillaries in the villi. Subsequently, the pressure is 20 mm Hg in the umbilical vein, returning to the heart.{{cite web |url=http://www.embryology.ch/anglais/fplacenta/circulplac01.html |title=Fetal and maternal blood circulation systems |publisher=Swiss Virtual Campus |accessdate=June 29, 2011}} ===Flow=== The blood flow through the umbilical cord is approximately 35 mL/min at 20 weeks, and 240 mL/min at 40 [[weeks of gestation]].{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/pd.1062 |title=The fetal circulation |year=2004 |last1=Kiserud |first1=Torvid |last2=Acharya |first2=Ganesh |journal=Prenatal Diagnosis |volume=24 |issue=13 |pages=1049–59 |pmid=15614842}} Adapted to the weight of the fetus, this corresponds to 115 mL/min/kg at 20 weeks and 64 mL/min/kg at 40 weeks. It corresponds to 17% of the [[combined cardiac output]] of the fetus at 10 weeks, and 33% at 20 weeks of gestation. [[Endothelin]] and [[prostanoid]]s cause [[vasoconstriction]] in placental arteries, while [[nitric oxide]] causes [[vasodilation]]. On the other hand, there is no neural vascular regulation, and catecholamines have only little effect. ==Prenatal heartbeat== {{Main|Heart development}} {{See also|Persistent fetal circulation}} ''Fetal cardiac activity'' (also called ''fetal heartbeat'' and usually called ''[[embryo]]nic cardiac activity'' before approximately 10 weeks of [[gestational age]]) is the rate of contractions during the [[cardiac cycles]] of an [[embryo]] or [[fetus]]. The heart is not fully developed when cardiac activity becomes visible. In cases of [[early pregnancy bleeding]], the detection of cardiac activity is the main finding that distinguishes a viable pregnancy from a [[silent miscarriage]]. ==Additional images== File:Embryo at 5 weeks 5 days with heartbeat.gif|[[Transvaginal ultrasonography]] of an embryo at 5 weeks and 5 days of [[gestational age]] with discernible heartbeat File:Neonatal Heart Circulation.png|Neonatal heart circulation ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=35em}} {{Development of circulatory system}} [[Category:Embryology of cardiovascular system]]
#REDIRECT [[Frauenkirche]]

'''Arroyo Seco Bridge''' may refer to the following bridges over the Arroyo Seco in California, USA: *The Washington Boulevard Bridge *The [[Mountain and Seco Streets|Seco Street Bridge]] *The [[Colorado Street Bridge (Pasadena, California)]], a concrete arch road bridge built in Pasadena in 1913 to carry Colorado Boulevard over the Arroyo *The [[Arroyo Seco Bridge (State Route 134)]], another concrete arch road bridge built immediately north of the Colorado Street Bridge in the 1950s to carry [[State Route 134 (California)|State Route 134]] over the Arroyo *The La Loma Bridge which carries La Loma Road over the Arroyo * The [[Santa Fe Arroyo Seco Railroad Bridge]] *The [[California State Route 110]] Bridge *The [[York Boulevard Bridge]] which on the east end becomes Pasadena Avenue; built in 1912 *The [[Interstate 5]] Bridge *The [[San Fernando Road]] Bridge *The [[Avenue 19 Bridge]], the last bridge before the Arroyo Seco flows into the [[Los Angeles River]]
{{disambiguation}}

(International title) | genre = [[Soap opera]] | creator = Ray Kolle

(as of 28 September 2018) [http://www.rtl.de/episode/unter-uns/Folge-5940.html Episode List] | runtime = 25 minutes | distributor = UFA Serial Drama | network = [[RTL Television|RTL]] | first_aired = {{Start date|1994|11|28|df=yes}} | website = http://www.rtl.de/cms/sendungen/unter-uns.html | website_title = Official website (German) }} '''''Unter Uns''''' (''Between Us'') is a German [[television]] [[soap opera]], first broadcast on [[RTL (German TV channel)|RTL]] on 28 November 1994. Centered on the lives of the people in a residential house, which is set in the [[fictional]] Schillerallee in [[Cologne]]. Since the show debuted the baker's family Weigel is the series core family. ''Unter Uns'' is not based on a foreign soap opera like ''[[Verbotene Liebe]]'' or ''[[Gute Zeiten, schlechte Zeiten]]''. After ''Gute Zeiten, schlechte Zeiten'', the show was the second daily soap for RTL, followed years later in 2006 by ''[[Alles was zählt]]''.
